title: china cash in coronavirus
story: THIS time last week, along with the rest of Fleet Street, I was writing Boris Johnson’s obituary.China had killed our Prime Minister, I said. I’ve never been so pleased to see my copy spiked.We now know from the PM himself just how close he came to death. But had things turned out dferently, my first sentence would still ring true.Boris would have paid the ultimate price for Covid-.The killer virus was spawned in China’s primitive “wet markets” and concealed by the country’s secretive communist regime and blamed by China on America and the West.Beijing’s claim of only , dead is a sick joke. The true figure could be ten times as high — or more.This, remember, is the regime that still lies about the thousands slaughtered in the  Tiananmen Square massacre.Yet China, having destroyed lives and livelihoods around the globe, is emerging as the big winner from its own pandemic.Like vultures hovering over roadkill, leaders of the world’s second-biggest economy are eyeing up the casualties of this made in-China calamity.Covid- risks opening the door to Beijing’s dominance over world trade and commerce, at unimaginable cost to our freedoms and democracy.Rattled world leaders, from Australia to Germany, are drafting emergency laws to prevent China mopping up crown jewels in pharmaceuticals, minerals, articial intelligence and robot technology.But it is probably too late. The West has turned a blind eye to China’s decades of industrial espionage and its cut-price grab for market share.Germany, Europe’s largest economy, is utterly dependent on cheap, heavily subsidised Chinese components and the VW and Mercedes car sales that account for a third of their profits.Suicidally, it will see Chinese cash as a passport out of the crisis.“We have grown too idle and too comfortable to want to do the things the Chinese do for us,” says a Cabinet insider.The world stood silent as China’s Belt And Road programme gobbled up key ports and industries, rare earth minerals and rich farmland across Africa and the Third World.Beijing is now rubbing its hands at the prospect of fresh bargains.Household-name firms here and in Europe are struggling to survive the lockdown. Some will never reopen their doors.The best might end up in Beijing at fire-sale prices.China has already seized a big stake in the UK with its richly subsidised £billion contract for the Hinkley Point nuclear power station in Somerset.Telecoms giant Huawei has its sticky fingers all over our sensitive G superhighway — a decision which must now surely be reversed.The image of communist China as a civilised equal partner is a dangerous fantasy.“China is not and never will be our friend,” a senior minister warns. “But it is the only one with ready cash and all our markets have collapsed because of something China started.“Our economy is being shattered and it is their fault. The idea of selling them some of our best companies is horrying.”China’s own economy has been hammered too. title: britains got talent lift nation
story: One random pull of a playing card and from that five of hearts he was able to predict Simon Cowell was, at that precise moment, subconsciously thinking about “a jetski”. And the moment before that.And probably every spare moment since he was obliged to leave the Sandy Lane Hotel, Barbados, to go through the motions at this old ITV circus, for the th time of asking.Britain’s Got Talent, which began with Ant and Dec sentimentally evoking all the things they love about this great country of ours.The White Clfs of Dover, Blackpool Tower, Edinburgh Castle, Russian sausage dog dancers, a Belgian contortionist, from Got Talent Espana, who scuttled across the stage in the spider position. That sort of quintessentially British thing.There was also, you probably sensed, a collective feeling Britain’s Got Talent didn’t just have a responsibility to lt the nation’s collective mood, over the following  minutes, but a moral duty.An unfair burden to put on any show and a forlorn hope, I thought, given the production has, for many years, involved nothing more inspirational than mixing and matching acts from the worldwide “Talent” franchise with the sort of homegrown sob stories which, however worthy and sincere, can feel a bit beside-the-point compared to the nightmare that’s just engulfed the world.And so it mostly proved on Saturday’s episode.Opinions here will dfer, I realise. In the latter category, though, we had a choir and foster care dancer Yakub, who won me over instantly with his modesty and tact as he announced: “My dream is to dance on . . . I’ve forgotten what I was going to say.” In the former, there was the Belgian contortionist, Papi Flex, an Indian dance troupe and Russia’s Diana Vedyashinka, who has spent the past  years teaching five dachshunds to stand hind-legged on a podium.An admission that made me feel slightly better about spending a similar amount of time watching EastEnders, but not much.There were also, of course, acts that fitted neither category, like James Piper, who’s “a personal trainer by day, magician by night”, meaning he can probably make haemorrhoids appear from nowhere.There was only one person, though, who genuinely lted the gloom.That was the brilliant comedian Steve Royle, from Phoenix Nights and Car Share, whose riotous act, pretending to shove ping-pong balls up his fundament, was funny enough even without the earnest health and safety caption from ITV: “Do not try this at home.” For five glorious minutes I forgot lockdown and began wondering about Steve’s next routine. Then I had to check myself.Because that is the sad and unavoidable issue with these BGT auditions. Unless they’ve got about  weeks of material, coronavirus means it’s a series currently going nowhere.Attempt to press ITV on this matter and all it can tell you is: “We are working with our production colleagues to see how we can make the BGT live shows work in an ever-changing situation.”Mind you, attempt to read Simon Cowell’s mind at the moment and I’m sure you’ll get a far more succinct response.“A jetski.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which month of the year was named after the Roman emperor Augustus Hardball, Ore Oduba: “Which animal has large breeds called Clydesdale and Shire ”Ben Shephard: “On a computer keyboard the abbreviation PGDN is short for page what ”And Ben Shephard: “Gerald Ford served as US President in which decade of the th century ”A BALLSY move, I thought, for ITV to screen a drama comedy about Who Wants To Be A Millionaire’s coughing cheats during the coronavirus outbreak.The dark irony is, though, it was the only show this past week that was good enough to make me forget the ongoing medical crisis for its duration.The second assumption was that Quiz would stand or fall on Michael Sheen’s impression of Tarrant.It doesn’t. And that’s probably just as well, as it’s a slightly hit-and-miss turn. One moment he’s Tarrant, the next he’s Tommy Cooper, but he always looks more like Les Dennis.Luckily for Quiz, however, it barely matters because James Graham’s script sings and Matthew Macfadyen delivers a performance that’s worthy of award nominations playing the thick-as-a-brick Major Charles Ingram. There are issues as well, obviously.Mark Bonnar’s accent sinks somewhere between Stranraer and Larne as Celador boss Paul Smith and there’s an air of ITV self congratulation in the opening hour about Millionaire’s ratings.A dangerous game to play when you’ve now got Secrets Of The Driving Test filling the show’s slot.All is forgiven and forgotten with tonight’s brilliant second instalmentthough, which concentrates on the coughing episode itself and the fallout, as ITV execs try to work out who they should call at Scotland Yard.“It’s the Celebrity Crime Squad.”“Really  It sounds like a s**t detective show.”“It sounds like something we’d make.”Quite.Manny Monthe: “- is a dangerous scoreline because the next goal wins.”Ian Wright: “Pep Guardiola came in and literally cut Joe Hart’s legs off.”Gary Lineker: “Rafa’s comeback in the Champions League final was his finest moment in the Premier League.”IN the continued absence of live sport, the contest of the week was The Great Celebrity Bake Off, on Channel , where two veteran camera-chasers battled it out for screen time and the winner’s apron.A Holly Willoughby on This Morning B Princess Fiona in Shrek The Musical ITV’s hugely entertaining drama Quiz. BBC’s nearly perfect World Cup Rewind series .The quietly brilliant BBC News health correspondent Fergus Walsh and his cameraman Adam Walker deserving awards for their coronavirus reports from UCL Hospital.And the bloke from pest control making a polite exit from Channel ’s The Mum Who Got Tourette’s: “Did Simon tell you I had Tourette’s ”“The thing that gave it away was when you opened the door and called me a c***.”Smug THIS week’s winner is Phillip Schofield and the Mekon from Eagle comic.Sent in by David Thompson, via email. title: pneumonia vaccine dr hilary questions
story: WE are now in a fourth week of the coronavirus crisis lockdown but many of you are still unsure of how best to protect yourself against the threat.That is why we have teamed up with TV’s Dr Hilary Jones, who has already answered thousands of your questions.Today, Dr Hilary – Health Editor for both ITV’s Good Morning Britain and Lorraine – tells Emma Pietras why it’s no use taking antihistamines to beat the virus and what certain pre-existing conditions can mean for you in the current situation.He also explains why we need to keep respecting social distancing.Q. I have had the pneumonia vaccine. Does that give us any protection against Covid- A. I’m afraid it doesn’t. It specically protects against infection with a nasty bacteria called pneumococcus, which can cause a secondary bacterial chest infection in someone who has a viral pneumonia, but the vaccine does not protect against coronavirus itself.Q. My family and I have been in isolation for  days as I had symptoms. My daughter and I are due to go back to work. If my daughter gets symptoms do we all have to isolate again A. Yes you do. If any of you develop the symptoms of a dry persistent coughor raised temperature the process starts again.Once more testing becomes available to people in your position, we will know whether you need to self-isolate for sure or not. Until then it’s better to be on the safe side.Q. Does taking antihistamines help fight the Covid- infection A. Antihistamines have nothing to offer in the fight against Covid-. They have no antiviral action.Q. Where can I buy the antibody test for Covid- A. Please don’t buy an antibody test for the virus. To my knowledge, there is no accurate, reliable, validated test commercially available, and those that are advertised are at ridiculously inflated prices.Any reliable tests which become available should be reserved for frontline doctors and nurses and their families who may be self-isolating so we can discover which of them are immune and are therefore safe to go back to work with patients.Q. I have a chest infection. Am I more likely to get the virus A. Chest infections cause inflammation within the breathing tubes and lung tissue, which can lower resistance to secondary infections.Viral infections are often complicated by bacterial infections and this would be the only reason why antibiotics might be used.So you should stay at home, avoid visitors and practise physical distancing so you are not exposed to the virus while slightly more vulnerable.Q. My we and I have self-isolated for more than two weeks, as have our two daughters and their families. Nobody shows any symptoms, so why can we not now see each other, respecting social distancing A. We are asking everybody during lock-down to stay at home as much as possible, to avoid public transport, to work from homethey can and only to go out for essential supplies and to physically distance themselves from other people when they do.The more people come into contact with others, the more the virus will spread. If one infected person gives the virus to one fewer person than has previously been happening, the infection rate among the population will fall by  per cent.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q. Do people living alone need to wash their hands as often or disinfect their home as often as those who live together A. For people who live alone the risk is much lower. title: boris nurses back on front line
story: THE two nurses credited by Boris Johnson with saving his le have gone straight back on to the coronavirus front line to help others.Ward sister Jenny McGee, , and staff nurse Luis Pitarma, , became global celebrities after the PM singled them out for praise over the le-saving treatment he received in intensive care at St Thomas’ Hospital, London.And yesterday Jenny’s brother Rob said: “She is very humble and is back at work now for another night sht.“She said she was just really pleased to see all the hard-working people in the NHS be recognised for the amazing work they are doing.“We are all very proud of Jen, not just in the support she gave Boris, but what she has been doing helping everyday people.“While she is blown away by Boris’s recognition, she is just really pleased to see the public recognition for the amazing work the NHS is doing — that made her really proud.”New Zealander Jenny has been in the UK for eight years. She came here to study then took a post at St Thomas’.Mum Caroline described her as an exceptionally friendly person and a dedicated nurse.She said: “It makes us feel exceptionally proud, obviously. But she has told us these things over the years and it doesn’t matter what patient she is looking after, this is what she does.”The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealCaroline said Jenny has described caring for the PM as surreal.She added: “Our daughter’s very professional so we don’t ask things and she doesn’t spill things. So it wasn’t until Boris was out of intensive care that she actually told us.“She said she’d just had the most surreal time in her le and that she had been taking care of Boris — something she’ll never forget.”Dad Mike added: “Over the years she has always told us that her job is one-on-one nursing with very critically ill people and that means she’s there all the time.“So once we’d heard that Boris Johnson had gone into intensive care it was obvious that at some stage Jenny would possibly run into him.“We knew she’d give him the same level of care she’d have given someone  the week before — or will be giving next week. We’re really proud of her.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Portuguese Luis, who moved to London in , is also believed to have gone straight back to work after Mr Johnson was discharged.One of his friends said yesterday: “He’s an amazing guy. This is really special. You just have to treat each patient that comes in and on this occasion it was the Prime Minister.“I think he’s totally gobsmacked by the reaction and the recognition he’s received. To have the Prime Minister praising you for saving his le is incredible.“He really is Luis the lesaver. He is a great guy.” Both Jenny and Luis were hailed as heroes yesterday back in their home countries.Sir Tim Shadbolt, mayor of Jenny’s home city of Invercargill, said: “It’s not very often a nurse from here saves the le of the British Prime Minister.”New Zealand’s prime minister Jacinda Ardern also sent Jenny a Facebook message of thanks. And Jenny’s old school, Verdon College, said it had the “sincerest admiration” for her.It added: “Jenny is described by her past teachers as an absolutely delightful person and someone who had a caring and humble nature.“Thanks Jenny for your courage, outstanding work and the example you have provided for everyone at this dficult time. Your old school community is so proud of you!” Luis, born in Aveiro nearPorto, was congratulated by Portugal’s president Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa during a phone call on Sunday.Mr Johnson paid tribute to the NHS medics who saved him in an emotional video message recorded on Sunday after he was discharged from hospital and reunited with pregnant fiancée Carrie Symonds.He gave a special mention to “Jenny from New Zealand and Luis from Portugal’ — saying they stood at his bedside for  hours when “it could have gone either way”.The PM also name-checked “Po Ling and Shannon and Emily and Angel and Connie and Becky and Rachael and Nicky and Ann”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: couple stunned hot tub office
story: Mark and Jenny Ronsman, from Wisconsin, US, bought their house three-and-a-half years ago and were told about the tub but only recently got around to fixing it.Mark, , said the previous homeowner, an elderly lady, had spoken to them about using the secret tub years ago but had since covered it over due to lack of use.He said: When we bought this house, we knew there was a hot tub in this room.But the elderly woman who sold us the house said they got older and stopped using it, so they converted it to an office.He added that the tub didnt look particularly inviting when the homeowner initially showed them photos.Mark added: She showed us an old photo of it filled with water and people back in the day but it didnt really give you a good feel for how the hot tub looked itself.One of the first things I did when we moved in was tear up that carpet and figure out what was going on.But after digging down into the floor, Mark and Jenny were delighted at what they found.Mark added: I was pleased to find the tile in the hot tub looks beautul! And its super deep!Im just now finally getting to fixing it up to run again. Hopefully soon while this lockdown is going on.Mark told the LadBible that the hot tub was close to completion, and will be ready to use in two to four weeks.The tub has been checked by a pool technician, but the couple still have to clean the tiles which will take around a week.After that, Mark says all thats left to do is clean the pipes and then fill up the tub.The systems engineer is already keen to move onto his next project, fixing up a s shuffle bowler arcade machine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mass grave london coronavirus
story: MASS graves have been dug in South East London as the number of dead from coronavirus continues to mount.The plots, which are ten yards long and two yards wide, were created at Kemnal Park Cemetery in Chislehurst for members of the Islamic community.Funeral directors claimed they had up to  people waiting to be buried. Traditionally, an Islamic burial should take place within  hours of death.However, the so-called saff graves — from the Arabic for row — are said to be in accordance with the Muslim faith.The cemetery’s Richard Gomersall said: “Funerals will take place in quick succession and in accordance with Islamic practice. We will not be cutting any corners.”Meanwhile, a vast temporary mortuary has gone up on Wanstead Flats, East London.Two bays and trollies were spotted at the site ahead of the arrival of the coronavirus dead.Soldiers were also on site at London’s NHS Nightingale hospital yesterday.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThey have been helping with planning and construction of the facility at the ExCeL centre.The military is also advising the NHS on creating another four hospitals around the country.Troops were also drafted in to deliver protective equipment while others will be driving ambulances.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Labouraposs new leadership team have announced an inquiry into a leaked document which alleges that Labour staff conspired to undermine Jeremy Corbynaposs bid to win the  general election and the partyaposs handling of anti-Semitism complaints.Keir Starmer has confirmed an investigation into the -page document, which was drawn up by allies of Mr Corbyn and claims that some senior Labour staff opposed to Mr Corbyn used the partyaposs own machinery to work against the then Labour leader.The internal investigation, leaked widely and seen in full by the Mirror, claims that factional opposition in the upper echelons of the party towards the Islington North MP contributed to a litany of mistakes that hindered the effective handling of anti-semitism. It also claims that party officials opposed to Mr Corbyn worked to lose the  general election in the hope that a bad result would trigger a leadership contest to depose him. In a joint statement, Mr Starmer and his deputy Angela Rayner launched an investigation into the claims made in the document, how the evidence in it was gathered and how it was leaked.  The statement said: “We have seen a copy of an apparently internal report about the work of the Labour Party’s Governance and Legal Unit in relation to antisemitism. The content and the release of the report into the public domain raise a number of matters of serious concern. “We will, therefore, commission an urgent independent investigation into this matter. This investigation will be instructed to look at three areas. First, the background and circumstances in which the report was commissioned and the process involved. Second, the contents and wider culture and practices referred to in the report. Third, the circumstances in which the report was put into the public domain. “We have also asked for immediate sight of any legal advice the Labour Party has already received about the report. “In the meantime, we ask everyone concerned to refrain from drawing conclusions before the investigation is complete and we will be asking the General Secretary to put measures in place to protect the welfare of party members and party staff who are concerned or affected by this report.” The report claims to have found no evidence of anti-Semitism complaints being handled dferently to other forms of complaint, or of current or former staff being motivated by anti-Semitic intent.

One government source said: “We’re clearly concerned about the economic impact of all of this but public health is the absolute priority right now. “It would be wrong to look like bean counters at the expense of saving lives.” But another Cabinet source stressed that the health of the economy and the public’s health were intricately linked. They claimed to the Mirror: “It’s not a binary choice between protecting lives and protecting the economy, we want to protect both.” The source said modelling and analysis were ongoing so officials know what trade-off decisions need to be made. Other elements including the impact of poverty on the public’s health and delays to healthcare for other conditions will also be part of considerations. But the source added: “I don’t see how you can have a conversation about lting lockdown when you are still seeing an increase in the number of deaths.”  There are fears a longer closure of schools will damage the ­prospects of poorer children. But government sources have denied Education Secretary Gavin Williamson is pushing for them to reopen. They told the Mirror: “Schools are closed until further notice and that won’t change until the scientic advice changes.” The government expects to extend the restrictions at a meeting on Thursday, with experts arguing that the UK is not yet through the worst of the pandemic. Tonight First Secretary of State and PM Boris Johnson ’s stand-in Dominic Raab thanked the UK public for staying at home over the Bank Holiday weekend. He said: “People should be in absolutely no doubt that, by staying home this weekend, you have saved lives, and you also helped protect our precious NHS at this critical moment in the crisis.” The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. He added: “We have come too far, lost too many loved ones and sacriced too much to ease up now.” Asked about plans to loosen lockdown restrictions, Mr Raab replied that it was “too early to talk about that”. After another  coronavirus patients died in UK hospital, the total stands at ,. It is the lowest increase recorded over the Bank Holiday weekend, after  on Friday, which surpassed the worst confirmed daily totals in Italy and Spain of  on Saturday and  on Sunday. But experts warned that the lower number was due to the holiday and not necessarily a sign of a slowdown.  Professor James Naismith of the University of Oxford added: “We will have to see further data before making any firm judgment as to trends.” Chief Scientic Officer Sir Patrick Vallance said: “When we are firmly the other side of it in terms of numbers coming down, only at that stage might we look at when those measures might be released.” The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies will meet today ahead of a decision on Thursday on whether or not to extend the lockdown. Figures show one in seven people who ended up in hospital with coronavirus in the UK have died. As of Sunday , people died with Covid- in NHS hospitals in England out of a total of almost , inpatients. It works out at a death rate of just over % for those who are admitted. story: NewsVirtual Parliament set to open as MPs demand debate on coronavirus responseMinisters will be grilled over webcam from April  - but the House of Commons Committee must still work out how it will work after MPs demanded greater scrutiny over how the Covid- crisis is being handledShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR NewsMinisters will be grilled over webcam" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The UK’s first “virtual parliament” is set to open next week after MPs demanded greater scrutiny of the how the coronavirus crisis is being handled. Ministers refused demands from Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer and other parties to recall Parliament.It will sit from April  as planned, but ministers will be grilled over webcam rather than in person as the battle to stop the spread of the virus continues. The House of Commons Commission will decide how the virtual parliament will work when it meets on Thursday. One option is for Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle to sit alone in the Commons chamber with MPs participating via video link. Ministers would also be required to appear remotely for ministerial question time sessions, urgent questions and other business relating to the House Commons. Another idea is for ministers and shadow ministers to appear in person as other MPs “dial-in”. Sir Keir said: “It’s very important in a crisis like this that Parliament is sitting so that decisions can be properly scrutinised.”

title: darren lewis keep seeing trite
story: NewsopinionDarren Lewis: We keep seeing trite claim that coronavirus does not discriminateWhen it comes to this virus we are definitely not all in it together, says Mirror Columnist Darren LewisShareCommentsByDarren Lewis:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsopinionCoronavirus is claiming more and more each day " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnd still they rise – the numbers of coronavirus deaths which illustrate the devastating rate at which it is decimating black and Asian households. Most weeks this column at least tries to reflect on le away from the issues plunging the country into collective depression. There is no escaping, however, the fear wrapping its tentacles around the section of our society disproportionately affected by this pandemic. Nor is there any escaping the fact that we are not all in it together. Not when the first  doctors in the UK named as having died from the coronavirus were all black, Asian or minority ethnic. And not when % of the people in intensive care are from the same demographic. When it comes to remaining indoors we don’t need to be told twice. We keep seeing that trite claim that the coronavirus does not discriminate. In reality you are more likely to be a victimyou have no choice but to work while others, in their big houses and on their laptops, tut-tut at you for not staying at home. You also have no choice but to squeeze onto the Tube when everyone  is tweeting how inconsiderate you are – without realising thatyou don’t work, you don’t eat. Nor do your kids. That pressure is not colour or heritage-specic. Millions of working class people of all races are in a similar position with fears over space, health and how they will feed their families.

A murder investigation has been launched after the -year-old grandmother was found at her Staffordshire home. She had been reported missing by concerned relatives on Motheraposs Day and officers later broke into her home and made a chilling discovery. Police said that the retired midwe had a severe blunt trauma head injury. More details of the her death emerged as an inquest was opened and adjourned at North Staffordshire Coroneraposs Court. It comes as police secured a European Arrest Warrant as part of their attempts to extradite a -year-old man from Sweden. They say they want to speak to the man in connection with her death. The inquest was told how Wendy had been reported missing by her daughter on Sunday, March  after she failed to get any response when she knocked on the door of her Tunstall Road home. Police soon broke in and made the terrible discovery.  North Staffordshire assistant coroner Sarah Murphy said: The circumstances reported to the coroneraposs court are that the deceased lived alone and was having building work done at the house. title: hero volunteer showing kindness helping
story: NewsHero volunteer who helped after Manchester bombing and Grenfell now supporting vulnerable in coronavirus crisisEXCLUSIVE British Red Cross volunteer Rukia Shepherd, , is part of an emergency response team looking after vulnerable people across the North West and helps struggling families every dayShareCommentsByClaire Donnelly:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsRukia with husband and kids" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Even away from the NHS front line, millions are doing their bit in the war against coronavirus.Whether offering to fetch shopping for a neighbour, looking after a key worker’s children or volunteering to help those most in need, people across Britain have responded by showing some good old-fashioned kindness. Among them is British Red Cross volunteer Rukia Shepherd, , who knows all about helping out in a crisis, having already helped victims of the Manchester Arena bombing and Grenfell Tower tragedy in  As more of you sign up to join our Kindness Will Keep Us Together campaign, Rukia tells us how it’s done – and why it’s so worthwhile. She says: “Someone said to me, ‘I bet you’re sick and tired of this’ – but I’m not. I take pride in volunteering. “Things are so awful at the minute but showing people kindness can make a big dference – to us all.” She is part of an emergency response team looking after vulnerable people across the North West, and works for eight hours a day delivering food and supplies to struggling families. As we speak, she is queuing in a supermarket to collect shopping for people who cannot get out. She has spent the day collecting PPE gear and delivering essentials to homeless shelters, sourcing a new walking stick for a disabled mum and arranging for a cot to be delivered to a mum who had nowhere for her newborn to sleep, as well as dropping off food parcels to vulnerable families.  It is late and she is tired, but she sounds upbeat as talks about her “brilliant” day. She says: “Seeing the look on those kids’ faces when I dropped their food off – laughing and all excited – that makes it all worthwhile. You know they’re going to eat well and be OK.” She adds: “There are so many people who can’t get out, who can’t help themselves right now – soI can do it for them, I will.” The primary school teaching assistant lives in Manchester with pharmacy delivery driver husband Howerd, , and their three teenage kids. She was working at a school where several pupils and teachers were caught up in the Arena bombing when the Red Cross appealed for volunteers.  Rukia came forward to help comfort victims’ families at the Royal Oldham Hospital. She says: “Nothing prepares you for a scene like that. There was a deafening silence. As well as the families the staff were in shock.” But even among the horror, volunteering brought her hope. “There was strength, kindness but most of all humanity,” she says. “I’d never experienced that feeling so strongly before.” Weeks later the Grenfell Tower tragedy unfolded. “My gut instinct was to go,” she says. She spent two weeks looking after severely traumatised residents who had lost everything. “I remember one man in particular,” she says. “He had lost his -year-old daughter and was too numb to speak. I struggled to not become emotional.” Rukia is partly motivated by wanting to repay the kindness she was shown as a vulnerable young woman living in poverty and facing homelessness. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. “Things weren’t very good for me, when I was about ,” she says. “I didn’t know where to turn really. “I went to the Citizen’s Advice and it was closing time. But the man there stayed to help me, he listened, made time for me when he didn’t have to. “Because of that I got the help I needed and I’ve never forgotten that – it made me realise how important it is to help and to listen.” Volunteering has also given her a sense of hope for the future. “When I go out in my workwear people smile at you as though they are comforted by your presence,” she says.People have asked me why I put myself through this. Being there has led me to see not just the worst but the best of humanity.

story: NewsHow to relieve mild symptoms associated with coronavirus – and when to seek helpTheres steps you can take at home to help ease mild symptoms associated with coronavirus, which include a fever, dry cough, fatigue and shortness of breathShareCommentsByLuke MatthewsAudience Writer:,  APR NewsHeres what you can do to ease potential symptoms " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe World Health Organizationhas said most people infected with Covid- will aposhave a mild disease and recoverapos. Those who do experience mild signs of the virus are being urged to self-isolate and stay at home to reduce the rate of transmission. Common symptoms include a fever, dry cough, fatigue and shortness of breath, and those experiencing less extreme symptoms are being asked not to visit a GP, pharmacy or hospital.Instead, you should recover at home and use the NHS  online serviceyou need medical advice. If you experience any symptoms, you should also self-isolate.The less extreme symptoms can usually be managed at home - but you also need to be aware of when it is appropriate to seek medical help. Hereaposs what you can do to help relieve the symptoms at home: Drink waterStaying hydrated is important to maintaining overall health and can relieve symptoms including headaches.Itaposs recommended to drink about two litres of water a day, but the amount needed can y from person to person.Nutritionist Amanda Ursell told The Sun urine is a good indication of hydration. She said: If it’s pale and clear that’s good. If itaposs dark orange and whfy, you need to drink more.You should also avoid alcohol as it can increase levels of dehydration. Take paracetamol The NHS advises to take paracetamol to lower your temperature, rather than ibruprofen.In response to concern that ibuprofen can make make symptoms worse, the NHS says: There is currently no strong evidence that ibuprofen can make coronavirusworse.But until we have more information, take paracetamol to treat the symptoms of coronavirus, unless your doctor has told you paracetamol is not suitable for you.  Rest and sleep One of the main symptoms associated with coronavirus is the feeling of fatigue, which can be caused by your body using energy to fight an infection and to recover. Sleep can help replenish energy and aid recovery, and you shouldnapost refuse the urge or rest or nap as it can prolong the illness. You shouldnapost do any vigorous exercise, which could put extra strain on your body, but light activity such as a walk may help you be able to sleep better.

It is now more than two months since the first coronavirus case was confirmed in the UK. Since the virus first began edging its way towards the UK public health officials have warned that new, persistent coughs and fevers are tell-tale signs of the disease. Other, milder symptoms have also become hallmarks of the disease in recent weeks. These include physical and mental fatigue, loss of sense of smell and a lack of appetite.As more and more people have been struck down by Covid- and understanding of the disease has grown, an even fuller list of symptoms has emerged. Do you have a coronavirus story  Email webnews@trinitymirror   A buzzing sensation One of the more curious ones is a buzzing sensation that runs through the body. While it has not been listed as an official symptom to watch out for, many people have posted online about experiencing a aposfizzingapos sensation. Tarana Burke, recognised as the founder of the #MeToo movement, said that her partner had the illness and the sensation that his aposskin felt like it was burningapos. Twitter user @Miafia described having “an electric feeling on my skin.” Dr Daniel Grfin, chief of infectious disease at ProHealth Care Associates in the US, has suggested the feeling may be part of an auto-immune response to a patientsapos nervous system. “Clearly it’s been identied, but we’re just not sure yet how widespread it is,” he told the New York Post. Dr Vipul Shah, Clinical Director at telehealth service Pack Health, suggested it may simply be people experiencing a fever for the first time. Needing the toilet Another mild symptom of coronavirus that is being reported with increased regularity is the need to go to the toilet more often. Dr Diana Gall explained to the Express : Digestion problems and changes in bowel habits - particularly looser stools and making more frequent trips to the toilet - are sometimes the first signs that you’re coming down with something, not just with this coronavirus.  However, diarrhoea has been reported as an early symptom in patients who have later tested positive for Covid-. A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, analysed data  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and found nearly  per cent had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain. Isla Haslam, , from Balham, South West London, experienced stomach problems while suffering with the coronavirus. She realised that what she first thought was the consequences of a lentil heavy dinner was in fact coronavirus when she began to feel feverish. Testicular pain The third, slightly less common symptom of the coronavirus, is testicular pain. Researchers from  Hard Medical School filed a case report about a -year-old man who tested positive for the virus, after going to hospital with a ‘stabbing pain’ in his testicles. While doctors could find nothing wrong with his  testicles, and CT scan showed damage in his lungs. Two days later, the man was diagnosed with Covid-.  Unfortunately, because the man had atypical symptoms, several other patients and doctors may have unknowingly been exposed to the virus. While it remains unclear whether or not his testicular pain was linked to the virus, other viruses have been known to affect the testicles. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for seven days. You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild.Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others as it can take  days for them to appear. DO NOT go to your GP or hospital. Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice. Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital.  Speaking to  MailOnline, Dr Viney, a surgeon in Birmingham, said: “There are certain viruses that can affect the testicles, such as mumps. “Only time will tellCOVID- also affects the testicles but it isn’t a symptom many of the patients I’ve dealt with have complained about. For most of them, their testicles are the least of their worries.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe must not forget the brave NHS workers who have lost their lives to the coronavirus. When the nation needed their dedication, kindness and expertise, they answered that call and, in doing so, paid the highest of prices. These were not just the very best of the health service. They were loved ones, mothers, fathers, sons and daughters. And many of them would be alive todaythey had been provided with the proper kit. For all the wild promises by ministers there is still a woeful shortage of personal protection equipment. Stories from those working in our hospitals, clinics and care homes should shame the Government. Doctors and nurses are putting their lives in danger every day because they do not have enough masks, gowns, gloves and goggles. Faces of the NHS heroes who have died during the coronavirus pandemic Many are having to pay for their own equipment or are having to re-use existing kit. Others have resorted to fashioning make-sht gowns from bin liners. Instead of taking responsibility for this shameful situation, Health Secretary Matt Hancock insinuated that NHS staff were being too profligate in using what he described as “precious” equipment. Essential PPE should not be a luxury that needs rationing. It should be a basic right of anyone working in our health service at this crucial time. This is especially the case when so few frontline workers have been tested so far. Boris Johnson did not stint in his praise for the NHS workers who saved his le. The National Health Service, the Prime Minister said, is the “best” and the “beating heart of this country.” If Mr Johnson wants to show genuine gratitude these words must be matched by some genuine action. The Prime Minister is rightly recuperating, but the Government must redouble its efforts in his absence. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. Our political leaders have compared this moment of national crisis to a time of war. If they want to draw comparisons with previous battles then they should act with the same urgency that was shown in previous campaigns. During the Second World War our assembly lines were reconfigured to provide the necessary munitions.  Our industries should be transformed on a similar scale to provide the masks, gowns, goggles and gloves our key workers need. That is why the Mirror is launching our “Protect Us” campaign on behalf of all those serving the country at its time of need. We are demanding PPE is provided for NHS staff, carers, cleaners, porters, transport workers and anyone  who may be at risk. In the First World War the way the heroes in the trenches were let down by the officer class was compared to lions being led by donkeys.In the campaign against the coronavirus our angels on the medical frontline are being commanded by dullards. You should no more consider requesting our NHS staff and carers to tend for the vulnerable without gowns and masks than you would countenance sending soldiers over the top without rles and helmets.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor  years Shi Zhengli has prepared to fight the deadliest panedmic the world has seen for a generation.The virologist, from Wuhan in China, is the aposBat Womanapos scientists who discovered the coronavirus gene sequence within days of the first reported case of the outbreak.But she was then aposmuzzledapos from revealing the truth about her incredible discovery in the fight against Covid-, fuelling fears of a cover up by the Chinese authorities. Zhengli is one of the worldaposs top researchers on coronaviruses and has discovered dozens of deadly SARS-like viruses in bat caves. She studied samples taken from some of the first people to become infected with the new and then-mysterious respiratory illness in China in December and found it was similar to SARS. It was identied as a novel coronavirus and within three days she completed its gene sequencing, finding that it was  per cent identical to a virus found in horseshoe bats in Yunnan, a process which can take monthsnot years. The claims are the latest to emerge after a cover-up by Chinese authorities who failed to share information or issue warnings early on and, ultimately, contain a virus that emerged in Wuhan and then spread around the world, leading to tens of thousands of deaths and more than a million confirmed infections.Chinese journalist Gao Yu said he spoke to Shi during his incarceration in Wuhan, which was locked down for more than two months, and she told him her findings were hushed up, the  Mail on Sunday  reported.The journalist added: We learned later her institute finished gene-sequencing and related tests as early as January  but was muzzled. The information about gene sequencing wasnapost made public until a week later. It is now being used around the globe in a race against time to find a cure and vaccine for the deadly bug, which has already infected more than .million people around the world and caused , deaths. For Zhengli the disocvery of the coronavirus gene sequence is the culmination of more than  years work, which has made her one of the worldaposs leading scientists in her field. But when the virologist received the fateful call on December  last year, just after the first patient samples had arrived at the lab in Wuhan, she admits she knew she would be about the battle her worst nightmare. And Zhengli had one overriding fear - had the new virus been accidentally unleashed by the lab she worked in. In the  years she had been working with bats, Zhengli had found the subtropical areas of China posed the biggest risk for the coronavirus being transmitted from animals to human - not the centre of the country where Wuhan is located. She said: I had never expected this kind of thing to happen in Wuhan, in central China. I remember thinking aposcould they have come from our lab apos Zhengli was at a conference outside Wuhan when she received the terrying phonecall that would change the course of the world. Two hospital patients had an unusual type of pneumonia and the Wuhan Center for Disease Control and Prevention needed Zhengliaposs expertise amid fears this new strain of the virus could be a deadly risk to public health. Her director told her to drop whatever you are doing and deal with it now and she was immediately on a train back to the lab in Wuhan. Zhengli and her team worked round the clock to find the genetic code of this new strain of coronavirus as the Covid- spread around the world like wildfire. But it was a moment she had spent her entire career working towards - starting with her first virus expedition back in . Zhengli travelled to bat colonies located in caves near Nanning, which she described as spellbinding. But the work was hard, with long hikes and risky decents into caves to find the creatures - and could often be frustrating. She was part of the team who were searching for the source of the SARS epidemic after a team from Hong Kong had reported that civets, which are similar to mongoose, had been the source of the virus and they were found in the subtropical parts of Asia and Africa. Before SARS the world had been blissfully unaware of the devastating impact of the coronavirus family but the epidemic led to a global push to both learn more and work to prevent a pandemic - and Zhengli was part of that early team. And the one thing that seemed to be key in the outbreak of a coronavirus was that they had started in bats before spreading to other animals and then humans. For months, work on the epedition was relentless with the team waking at dusk to work ovrnight when the bats had left the caves to hunt for food. They would collect blood, saliva and fecal swabs before grabbing a few hours sleep only tothe following morning to collect urine. For weeks there was no sign of coronavirus in the DNA that had been collected. Zhengli was heartbroken. She said: Eight months of hard work seemed to have gone down the drain. We thought coronaviruses probably did not like Chinese bats. At the end of their patience, the team were about tohome when another lab gave them a diagnostic kit for testing antibodies produced by people with SARS. Admitting she didnapost have high hopes it would work, Zhengli said she had nothing to lose by testing the samples and the results were incredible and was a turning project for the scheme. Antibodies against SARS were found in three species of horseshoe bats, which meant they were one step closer to finding the genetic code. After testing a huge number of sites, the team then narrowed their search down to the outskirts of Kunming, the capital of Yunnan and for the next five years they targeted their research on that area. Horryingly, the team discovered hundreds of strains of coronaviruses but thankfully just dozens were similar to SARS, could infect human lungs and were immune to vaccines and cures that had proved successful against other forms of the virus. And finally, in one cave, the scientists found what seemed to be the epicentre for SARS - but this came with an added risk. It meant millions of bats were mixing and creating increasing opportunities for the virus to evolve and for new strains to emerge. They also found that the virus could spread to those who werenapost directly handling the animals. People living in a nearby village had seen bats flying around. Six people had suffered from symptoms similar to SARS. And this was not the only time Zhengli and her team had found evidence bats were spreading a new strain of the deadly virus. Six miners had been struck down with an illness similar to SARS and when Zhengli investigated the mineshaft where they were working, they discovered it was covered in a disgusting-smelling fungus. The mine was closed immediately to prevent a coronavirus outbreak. Zhengli fears that the more humans move into areas previously havens for wildle, the greater the risk of unleashing new coronaviruses on the population. This coupled with the movement of wildle and livestock around the world, along with increased long-haul travel, creates conditions perfect for the potential spread of a pandemic - something Zhengli has long feared. A year ago, Zhengli and her team published a study warning of the potential of a bat-borne pandemic. Little did they know just  months later their doomsday predictions would come true. Then, at the turn of the year, everything they had been preparing for for the last  years suddenly needed to kick into action. Amplying the genetic material of the virus using the polymerase chain reaction technique Zhengli and her team found five of the infected patients had the same genetic sequences found in all coronaviruses. Zhengli admits she didnapost sleep at all during those first few days of frantic testing and a week after the first case had been reported she was certain a new strain of coronavirus has caused the sickness that had killed the patients - and Covid- was born. Chillingly, it also showed there had been just one point where the virus had passed from animals to human and had then spread through human to human contact - until it covered the world. They also found the virus could have been in existance for months but hadnapost started to spread until it reached Wuhan - and its wildle markets where animals are sold, slaughtered and skinned, as customers browse the stalls. They sell a range of creatures, such as bats, civets, pangolins, badgers and crocodiles, although Zhengli and her team believe the virus came directly from the bats themselves. Almost two months after the first cases of the virus emerged in Wuhan, China permanently banned wildle consumption and trade. It is estimated this will forced million people out of work and cost the Chinese economy about £billion, however, Zhengli believes the consumption and trade of wildle is not the whole problem. Bats are believed to have responsible for six outbreaks of coronaviruses, including the Covid- pandemic, but experts insist problems only occur when people come into contact with the creatures themselves.Le is Wuhan is slowly ing to normal, although China has recorded its highest number of daily new  coronavirus  cases in almost six weeks, sparking fears of a second wave of Covid- after restrictions were eased.A total of  new coronavirus cases were reported in mainland China on Sunday, up from  a day earlier and marking the highest number of cases since  infections were reported on March . But for two months Zhengli barely left her lab and survived on nothing but instant noodles as she and her team worked to not only identy the virus but come up with the key to a cure. The found how it gets into human lungs and are now working on drugs that can block it, as well as trying to come up with a vaccine and trial it on people. Zhengli describes the Wuhan outbreak as a wake-up call for the world and work is now taking place around the globe to find a way to prevent another pandemic.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailChina has recorded its highest number of daily new coronavirus cases in almost six weeks, sparking fears of a second wave of Covid- after restrictions were eased. Officials say the sudden rise is due to infected travellers arriving from abroad, many of them crossing the border from Russia. A total of  new coronavirus cases were reported in mainland China on Sunday, up from  a day earlier and marking the highest number of cases since  infections were reported on March . Heilongjiang province, which borders Russia in the north-east, has become Chinaaposs new battleground against Covid- as the rise threatens to push the entire country back into a state of near paralysis. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror. The National Health Commission said  of the new cases - or more than  per cent - were imported, a new record. A total of  Chinese nationals who entered Heilongjiang province from Russia tested positive. Our little town here, we thought it was the safest place, said a resident of the border city of Suenhe, who only gave his surname as Zhu. Some Chinese citizens they want to come back, but itaposs not very sensible, what are you doing coming here for   Though the number of daily infections across China have dropped sharply from the height of the epidemic in February, China has seen the daily toll creep higher after hitting a trough on March  because of the rise in imported cases. Chinese cities near the border with Russia are tightening border controls and imposing stricter quarantines in response to influx of infected patients from the country.  Suenhe last week announced restrictions on movements and gatherings similar to those imposed in Wuhan city, where the coronavirus outbreak first emerged late last year, and extended the closure of its border with Russia. The land route through the city had become one of few options available for Chinese nationals trying to get into China after Russia stopped all flights to the country.  Suenhe and Harbin, capital of Heilongjiang, are now mandating  days of quarantine for all arrivals from abroad as well as nucleic acid and antibody tests. Streets in Suenhe were virtually empty on Sunday evening due to restrictions of movement. Residents said a lot of people had left the city as the number of infected people crossing the border from Russia rose. I donapost need to worry, Zhao Wei, another Suenhe resident, told Reuters. If thereaposs a local transmission, I would, but thereaposs not a single one. Theyaposre all from the border, but theyaposve all been sent to quarantine. In Shanghai, authorities found that  people who arrived on Aeroflot flight SU from Moscow on April  have the coronavirus, Zheng Jin, a spokeswoman for the Shanghai Municipal Health Commission, told a press conference on Monday.  China has cut the number of people crossing its borders by  per cent and has tried to stop all non-essential journeys, said Liu Haitao, an immigration official, at a separate briefing on Monday. Our border is long, and apart from the border crossings and passages, there are a large number of mountain passes, paths, ferry crossings and small roads, and the situation is very complicated, he said. Pang Xinghuo, deputy director of the Center for Diseases Prevention and Control in Beijing, said the trend for local transmission of the disease in the capital was low. Imported cases are still the highest risk in Beijing in the second half of April, Pang said, adding that nearly eight per cent of the , nucleic acid tests carried out in the city since April  had been conducted on people who had come from abroad. The total number of confirmed cases in mainland China now stands at , as of Sunday.  At the peak of the first wave of the epidemic on February  there were over , new cases. Though the number of daily infections across China has dropped sharply from that peak, China has seen the daily toll creep higher after hitting a trough on March  because of the rise in imported cases. China has been accused of underreporting its total number of infections. China hid work of Bat Woman scientist China is accused of hiding the findings of a coronavirus expert - known as Bat Woman - after she quickly identied the genetic make-up of the new strain that has infected millions. Wuhan-based virologist Shi Zhengli is one of the worldaposs top researchers on coronaviruses and has discovered dozens of deadly SARS-like viruses in bat caves. She studied samples taken from some of the first people to become infected with the new and then-mysterious respiratory illness in China in December and found it was similar to SARS.  It was identied as a novel coronavirus and within three days she completed its gene sequencing, finding that it was  per cent identical to a virus found in horseshoe bats in Yunnan. But she was muzzled and her team was ordered not to reveal any information about the new disease, which was already spreading rapidly as China kept the world in the dark. The claims are the latest to emerge after a cover-up by Chinese authorities who failed to share information or issue warnings early on and, ultimately, contain a virus that emerged in Wuhan and then spread around the world, leading to tens of thousands of deaths and more than a million confirmed infections. Chinese journalist Gao Yu said he spoke to Shi during his incarceration in Wuhan, which was locked down for more than two months, and she told him her findings were hushed up, the Mail on Sunday reported. The journalist added: We learned later her institute finished gene-sequencing and related tests as early as January  but was muzzled. The information about gene sequencing wasnapost made public until a week later. The day that the genetic information was mapped, Yanyi Wang, director of the Wuhan Institute of Virology, ordered staff not to reveal any information about the disease, it is claimed. After local doctors were detained for warning locals about the virus, the director claimed inappropriate and inaccurate information was causing general panic.  She ordered staff not to post any information on social media or speak to the media. Just over a week later, a team in Shanghai published a sequence on an open access  after studying samples from an infected patient. Their laboratory was shut for rectication two days later. One of the earliest Covid- cases emerged in mid-December when a patient, who worked at a wildle market in Wuhan that became the early epicentre of the outbreak, was hospitalised with a double lung infection in the city in central China. The usual treatment for flu-like illness failed to work and new cases soon emerged. The coronavirus lockdown is a worrying time for millions across the UK. But itaposs also bringing out the best in people who are selflessly giving their time each day to help those most in need. Our Mirror Coronavirus Heroes series wants to recognise all of those helping the most vulnerable during the crisis. Whether itaposs a local business going the extra mile for the community or a teenager helping an elderly neighbour, we want to hear about it. You can email your stories of Mirror Coronavirus Heroes to webnews@mirror. On December , Wuhan health officials were told that the illness was being caused by a new coronavirus. Three days later, at least two doctors from Wuhan - Li Wenliang and Ai Fen - shared information about the new virus on the social network WeChat. Li, a whistleblower who was warned by police to stop making  comments, died in February after contracting the virus. Ai is missing after giving media interviews criticising Chinaaposs censorship and hospital authorities for suppressing early warnings of the outbreak. She told the Chinese magazine, Renwu, or People, that she was reprimanded after alerting her bosses and colleagues of the new virus in December.  On  December, she received the laboratory results of one case which stated: SARS coronavirus. The next day, Wuhan officials confirmed almost  cases, shut down the wildle market and notied the World Health Organisationaposs local office about the mysterious illness. New cases continued to emerge and the outbreak was spreading outside of China, but for a week in January health officials in Wuhan insisted they had not received any new patients. During that time, the first known case outside of China was detected in Thailand and a case was reported in the US as infected people left Wuhan and surrounding Hubei province to travel across the country and around the world. Chinese authorities insisted they hadnapost seen any clear evidence that the virus could be spread from human to human.  By then they had lost control and hospitals were becoming overwhelmed by the rising number of infected patients. Within days Dr Zhong Nanshan, the countryaposs top respiratory expert and the face of its containment effort, revealed that human transmission was taking place. Wuhan and several other cities struggling to contain the virus went into lockdown on January , days before the Lunar New Year holiday, but by then millions of people had left without being screened. That day, Shi Zhengli and her research team published their data identying the illness on a scientic portal before it was published in February by the medical journal Nature. In the weeks that followed the lockdown in Wuhan, the virus rapidly spread to and within other countries due to imported cases and community transmission.  China is still censoring academic research into the origins of the new strain of coronavirus. The authorities have placed new restrictions on the publication of research that could shed new light on how it was passed from an animal to a human. All academic papers are being given extra vetting before being submitted for publication, it emerged on Monday. Studies must be approved by the central government before they are shared with the rest of the world, according to since-deleted online posts by two Chinese universities. A researcher told CNN that the new restrictions were another attempt by China to cover up its failures and would likely disrupt important scientic research. The researcher, who spoke on condition of anonymity due to fear of retaliation, added: I think it is a coordinated effort fromChinese government to controlnarrative, and paint it asthe outbreak did not originate in China. And I donapost think they will really tolerate any objective study to investigate the origination of this disease. PPE bound for UK held up by red tape Meanwhile, personal protective equipmentis being sent from China to the UK amid shortages at healthcare facilities in Britain and the deaths of almost  NHS workers. However, much of the kit from China is unusable because it fails UK safety checks.  Some shipments are being held up by red tape in China, the worldaposs biggest supplier of PPE, and some are wrongly labelled and do not contain the right gear, it has emerged. For example, a crate is labelled gowns but it contains masks instead. Chris Hopson, chief executive of NHS Providers in England which represents hospital trusts, told BBC Breakfast there were concerns about a shortage of PPE in some hospitals. Stocks of gowns have run critically low, he added. Mr Hopson said the supply of gowns - imported from China - was hand-to-mouth. He said in a televised address to the nation: Over the next four weeks, the rules must be respected. He also apologised for his government aposnot being prepared enoughapos for the crisis. Were we sufficiently prepared  Obviously not – no one is prepared for a crisis of this magnitude, he said. Macron added that by May , France would be able to test every citizen presenting Covid- symptoms and schools would be gradually reopened. George Eaton, senior online editor for the New Statesman, tweeted: It will be surprisingthe UK doesnapost mirror this. It comes as Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab today said that it is far too early to talk about relaxing Covid- lockdown measures in the UK despite positive signs from official data. Speaking at Mondayaposs Downing Street press conference, Mr Raab said figures indicated the UK was starting to win this struggle against the virus but warned it was still not past the peak. He praised the British public for staying at home during the Easter weekend, adding: Our plan is working. Please stick with it and weaposll get through this crisis together.  Meanwhile, Macron admitted his country had not been sufficiently prepared early on to face the challenges posed by the outbreak of the coronavirus, but said the unprecedented restrictions put in place had started showing results. He said: The epidemic is starting to slow down. The results are there. Thanks to your efforts, everyday we have made progress. But our country was not sufficiently ready for this crisis. Franceaposs residents have been under lockdown for four weeks - they must stay at home except to buy food, go to work, seek medical care or get some exercise on their own.  As part of the package of support for people affected by the crisis, he also announced aid for lowest-income families and students. The country will also keep its borders with non-European nations closed until further notice, he said. After a relentless increase until the first week of April, the number of patients in French hospitalsapos intensive care units has started to decline, but nursing homes have reportedly been overwhelmed.  France has so far reported , deaths linked to Covid-, with more than , confirmed cases, according to official figures. Although Macronaposs popularity initially shot up after he followed Italy and Spain in introducing drastic curbs on public le, his government has faced accusations of failing to address a shortage of masks and testing kits. Meanwhile, three weeks into the nation-wide lockdown in the UK Mr Raab said the Government did not expect to make any changes following a review of social-distancing measures by the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieslater this week. Mr Raabaposs comments came after the coronavirus-related hospital death toll passed ,, with the Foreign Secretary facing questions over whether more lives could have been savedthe UK had acted faster.  He rejected any like-for-like comparison with other countries, saying it depended on each nationaposs inidual circumstances and how far along the coronavirus outbreak curve they were. But the Governmentaposs chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said the UK would be looking to learn from other countries on how they approach releasing lockdown measures. Questions were also raised about whether the number of coronavirus-related deaths in care homes were being properly recorded.  Englandaposs chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said he wanted testing in the sector to be increased due to the large numbers of vulnerable people at risk. The Department of Health said , people had died in hospitals as of pm on Sunday, with many more expected in care homes. It means the UK has more recorded deaths than any country except the US, Italy, Spain and France.  Mr Raab admitted the government had been concerned that the public might start ignoring the advice or cutting corners given the temptation to go out into the sunshine over the Easter weekend. But he added: In fact the overwhelming majority of people stayed at home and understood the importance of doing so. By staying home this weekend, youaposve saved lives. Earlier Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman maintained the UK was still on course to carry out the Governmentaposs pledge of , coronavirus tests a day by the end of the month as he said , had been conducted in the  hours to Sunday morning.
