title: A tribute to Drumaness sportsman Roly Hanna
story: ldquoARGUABLY the best known and most liked character ever to have played for Drumaness Mills. No matter where you go or who you are talking to up and down the country, they always ask about Roly. There is always someone who knows him or has played with or against him.The above paragraph was taken word for word from Drumaness Millsrsquos th anniversary booklet in . It captures brilliantly the essence of Roly lsquoThe Manrsquo.Roly died on Wednesday, March , sparking a deluge of tributes on social media. True gentleman, one in a million, what a lovely man, one and only Roly, top man, a legend mdash these tributes, among many others, appeared again and again.Roly was an integral part of village le in Drumaness, dandering to the bookies or the shop. He would make multiple stops to say hello to everyone he met, discussing the issues of the day.I have known him for a!most  years. He worked in Sam Bellrsquos egg factory across the road from St Josephrsquos Primary School in Crossgar. The workers would kick a ball about the road during their break and even to my untrained eye he was dferent class. It was my introduction to Roly lsquoThe Footballerrsquo.Some years later Roly and his brother, John, knocked on our door in Crossgar. They wanted me to play for the Mills in the Newcastle Summer League and I was more than happy to do so.Playing with Roly was a great education for a young player. He made football look easy, was stylish and talented, possessing the rare gt of keeping the game simple.Small wonder then that when talk comes around to the Millsrsquo greatest ever player, Roly is always in the conversation, despite competition from the likes of Robbie Strain, Osie Gelston, Conor Walsh and Davy Mills.Legend has it that in those days boys were born with boots on in Drumaness because this was a village where sport was king. So it was that Roly also excelled at billiards and cricket, reaching a very high standard in both.But football and the Mills were Rolyrsquos first loves and he rarely missed training or matches. Inevitably his talent came to the notice of Irish League managers and he enjoyed spells with Portadown and Cltonville in the early seventies. Nevertheless, Roly was a home bird and sooner or later he would pull on the Mills shirt again.By now I was playing for the all conquering Downpatrick Rec team of that era and we pitched up to a Border Cup final early in  to play the Mills. We had just won the Steel and Sons Cup and had our eyes firmly on the double, but Roly and Osie Gelston had other plans and proceeded to inspire the Mills to a famous - win.Roly had reached the twilight years of a glorious footballing career, but there was still time to lead the Mills reserves to another giant-killing act, beating Castlewellan in the Bobby Dalzell Cup final in .After such a stellar playing career, Roly was expected to become a manager. He did dip his toes in the managerial waters once or twice, but with no offence intended to the managerial fraternity mdash myself included mdash Roly was probably too nice to be a manager. In all the years I have known him I canrsquot remember him raising his voice. He was just so easy going, decent and level-headed.As a result people liked Roly and this popularity unsurprisingly proved to be an asset in his working le. After Sam Bells he spent a number of years working in the Co-Op shop in Drumaness before taking up employment with well-known butcher Vincy Doran.He was a familiar sight in Vincyrsquos van, delivering to hotels and restaurants, but it was his weekend door-to-door run which played to his strengths and further cemented his popularity.He became known as Butch or Butcher mdash a nickname he loved mdash and Vincy to this day has nothing but good things to say about Rolyrsquos eight-year stint with him.Rolyrsquos next stop was with Jimmy Quinn, who owned a bakery in Downpatrick. Jimmy shrewdly ed Roly to the door-to-door market and with people still finding it dficult to say no to the personable Roly, their successful liaison continued for  years.Jimmy likes nothing better than relating Roly stories,none of which can be repeated here, and like the rest of us he will remember Roly with the utmost fondness.Unfortunately Roly wasnrsquot immune to the ups and downs of le and deteriorating health curtailed his working le. He managed to fight and beat prostrate cancer a number of years ago, but this time around the lsquoBig Crsquo has claimed this lovely man.Ironically it was during these latter years that he seemed to be ever present on the streets of Drumaness, allowing him to befriend a generation entirely unaware of his past sporting prowess.Roly married Betty Rice on October , , and together they brought Noel, Pauline, Betty, Carol and Christine into the world. After almost  years together as a couple they remained best friends, as well as husband and we.Apart from my football connection to Roly, I have been his neighbour for  years and since his passing I have heard him described as lsquoMr Drumaness Millsrsquo, but for me he was Mr Drumaness full stop. This village will never be the same without him.Rolyrsquos family should be immensely proud of his impact on those who knew him and how sad it was to see coronavirus rob them and Roly of the fitting send-off he deserved.However, the good news is that I know there are plans afoot to have a celebration of his le when normality s. Nobody deserves it more. RIP Roly.Roly Hanna -.prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass golfer on teeing up with the best in the world
story: ARDGLASS golfer Cormac Sharvin could be forgiven for feeling understandably frustrated right now.The richly talented  year-old should be locking horns with some of the worldrsquos best players on the European tour.But instead of prowling the fairways hersquos holed up in his apartment in Dublin mdash like many others undergoing coronavirus lockdown.Itrsquos not how Sharvin, currently th in golfrsquos world rankings, thought his first season on the European Tour would go.Having secured his card for the  season by finishing th on the  Challenge Tour rankings, he was gearing up for a potential breakthrough campaign on the top circuit.However, after just four events, he is unsure of what the future holds as the sporting world goes into shutdown due to the coronavirus outbreak.He clearly appreciated that golf, and sport in general, is of minor importance when compared with the COVID pandemic.Of the decision to close all golf courses north and south of the border, he told the BBC recently: ldquoItrsquos a precaution that needs to be in place.I donrsquot know enough about the virus, but theyrsquore obviously trying to slow things down. Hopefully wersquoll be back playing as soon as possible, I think thatrsquos the goal.ldquoI think we just have to accept it and sit tight and when it does pass, we can get things moving a bit quicker.Certainly things have happened fairly quickly for Sharvin in his career to date. He only took up golf seriously relatively late in his teenage years, but went on to have glittering amateur career.In  he was a member of the Great Britain and Ireland Walker Cup team, contributing three points and remaining unbeaten in a .-. thumping of the United States.Sharvin turned  the following year and joined the ranks of the European Challenge Tour.Having missed his European Tour card by a single shot in , Sharvin relocated to Dublin and It proved to be the right move.He amassed eight top ten finishes in  starts to earn a rookie season on the European Tour thanks in large part to his six top fives.Sharvin only missed four cuts, two of which came in the first two events of the season, before he kickstarted his campaign with back-to-back top ten finishes.However, his best performance came at the Irish Open at Lahinch where he finished tied for th and was also the leading Irish golfer.He showed impressive consistency during the  season and proved his elite-level credentials with a tie for th finish at the Irish Open, ending the week as the leading home competitor.He says: I had a really good year, I put myself into contention a lot which was great. I think I was ready to take that step and I think the way I played, I deserved to get my card in the end with a few good results.ldquoI also managed to play well in a couple of European Tour events as well which showed me that I was ready to take that step. Therersquos a relief that I have my card now but itrsquos only the start of it mdash I know I have to keep improving and moving up the rankings.At the Irish Open he finished ahead of future Open champion Shane Lowry, Ryder Cup star Tommy Fleetwood former world number one Lee Westwood and Ryder Cup captain Padraig Harrington.ldquoIt was disappointing to shoot level-par on Sunday, but I feel like I didnrsquot do much wrong, he said.ldquoIt was really nice to have that pressure of going into the final round of a big European Tour event with a chance to win. It showed me where I was mentally and physically, that I was able to come from the Challenge Tour and compete in a top-level European Tour event.ldquoThat was an unbelievable week. The crowds were incredible and I attracted a big following being the leading Irishman, and that was a great feeling.ldquoItrsquos a nice feeling when hundreds of people are following you and everyone is willing your ball into the hole. I think that really geared me up quite a lot. It was a class buzz.ldquoIt was dficult going back to playing the Challenge Tour in the middle of nowhere in France the week after, but that week gave me the confidence to string together more good results to get off the Challenge Tour.Sharvin admits itrsquos been a slow start on the European Tour, with a tie for th in the Oman Open his bestin four starts this year, but his belief in being able to compete at the higher end of leaderboards remains undimmed.ldquoI feel like my game is good, but I havenrsquot really put all the facets together. ldquoI think in Oman I was second in strokes, gained tee-to-green and just putted really poorly. I played quite nicely in Qatar and just didnrsquot get it going.ldquoItrsquos obviously such a short period of time so itrsquos hard to assess in four events, but I feel like Irsquom close. This break may help me improve other things and hopefully Irsquom a better player when we start again.Given his Walker Cup experience, Sharvin would dearly love to play in the Ryder Cup in the years ahead.ldquoThe Ryder Cup would definitely be up there for me. I grew up playing team sports and have been involved with them my whole le, so that would be huge.ldquoI feel like Irsquom pretty good in a team and having tasted a little success in team sports, I think thatI can get my game to that level, Irsquod be a good asset in that sense..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch singer performs at nursing homes
story: A BALLYNAHINCH man is serenading residents in local nursing and residential homes through the COVID- crisis with hit songs to remind them of happier times.The gesture from popular singer Wayne Rodgers is even more laudable as he lost all his work overnight in the lockdown as a driving instructor and a wedding band performer.The  year-old performed outside four homes on Monday, delighting the residents and carers in Redburn Nursing Home, Oakridge Care Home, Spa Nursing Home and Fishbourne House Care Home.Performing classic hits from artists such as Jim Reeves and Clf Richards, Wayne believes his singing is helping strike a chord with the elderly residents who need to be kept apart from family members at this time.ldquoThe singing helps the residents and it really helps me too as it passes the time for me as my work has had to stop due to the virus, said Wayne, who now lives in Bellaghy.ldquoIrsquove received photographs taken from the inside of the home showing residents enjoying my songs and itrsquos lovely to see. It can get really emotional as there are now family members turning up to wave and talk to their relatives through windows while I sing.ldquoItrsquos heartfelt to see their enjoyment at being able to connect with their parents or grandparents inside. It can be heart-breaking at times but itrsquos still nice to see it.ldquoI have been told by some of the carers that they have seen some patients with dementia sing along to the music and thatrsquos also really good to know.A former soloist with St Patrickrsquos Church in Ballynahinch and ex-pupil of St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College, Wayne ensures he keeps the residents and carers safe at all times.A long extension power lead from the home is laid for him before he arrives so he can plug in his mixing desk, microphone and laptop.Wayne said: ldquoItrsquos sterilised before I get it and when I had it back itrsquos sterilised again so I have no direct contact with anyone in the home.ldquoI try not to sing beyond  minutes as the homes often open the windows to allow residents to hear better and Irsquom conscious of not wanting anyone to get too cold in the process.Wayne started off singing at a Magherafelt nursing home when a pub owner hersquos friendly with was approached by the home asking for suggestions at how they could entertain the residents.He added: ldquoThe residents in the home loved it and asked me to come back again so I did and then I got calls from other homes.He now has nine performances under his belt with the help of his brother-in-law, former Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin, and his sister, Michelle, who runs Paddy Kellyrsquos Bar in Ballynahinch.Wayne, whose parents Maurice and Naveen still live in Ballynahinch, has been a show band singer for years and once performed with the legendary Sunshine.Gigs for his wedding band, The All Stars, have been cancelled or postponed as couples were force to rebook their wedding dates.Wayne is performing free of charge and says he is happy to as it gives him some focus in his le at this time.ldquoI donrsquot have much  to do as work has stopped, but I do feel a lot better knowing that Irsquom bringing some happiness to others, he added..prettyPhoto

title: Binmen receiving thank you messages for essential work
story: THE districtrsquos binmen have been thanked for continuing to provide collection services during the coronavirus pandemic.Some people have been pasting messages on their bins thanking the men for the job they are doing, while their efforts have also been commended by Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey.Working in extremely dficult circumstances, the binmen are providing a critical service at this time and their efforts have not gone unnoticed by ratepayers who taking time to wipe the handles of their bins with disinfectant before they are collected to help keep refuse staff safe.Householders are also being reminded to ensure that they continue to place the correct waste in the right bin to help ease the burden on public health services to help stop additional risks to staff who are working under increasing pressure.Refuse collection staff have been singled out for particular praise as they collect and transport waste, with their work also helping to protect the environment.Stormont environment minister Edwin Poots said the materials refuse staff collect for processing such as cardboard, plastic and glass are vital resources in package production across the food and retail sectors, explaining that ain recycling could impact on the supply chain ing effectively.He added: ldquoAll those working in the waste sector are key workers and I have also established a COVID- Waste Group to provide support, guidance and regulatory direction to the waste sector.Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash which recently closed all its household recycling centres to redeploy staff to work in refuse collection mdash said that all bin collections continue as normal.However, residents are asked to provide additional help by ensuring that bins are put out for collection no later than am every morning or the night before.Where possible, residents are asked not to restrict bin lorry access and park as considerately as possible. Over recent weeks, binmen have experienced issues accessing homes in a number of areas including Ballynahinch and Newcastle to collect bins.Residents are also asked to ensure that all bin handles are cleaned or wiped-down before and after use and not to approach refuse staff without following the minimum two-metre social distancing guidance.Commending refuse staff for the work they are doing in dficult circumstances, the council chairman explained that as the coronavirus crisis unfolded, the local authority was quick to implement a number of health and safety measures to protect staff.He explained that the measures allowed bin collection teams to continue the service with minimal disruptions to residents.ldquoCrews now operate staggered start times between .am and am and are authorised to leave work immediately upon the completion of their rounds, said Cllr Casey.ldquoTo support social distancing, crews are restricted to one driver and one loader in each cab. For crews that operate as one driver and two loaders, the loaders are transported behind the collection lorry in a support vehicle.ldquoLoaders are also asked to limit their time in cabs to an absolute minimum and can be collected and drop-off points along designated routes.Cllr Casey said the local authority is constantly reviewing its services in light of ldquorapidly changing events and may make further changes at very short notice.He said the current situation remains challenging and is dependent on the ongoing impact of COVID- on council employees.The chairman continued: ldquoWe would like to thank all our frontline workers who continue to engage with our residents to deliver essential services.ldquoI fully appreciate the disruption this has had on normal working routines. However, as a workforce and a wider-society we are now having to make signicant changes to our daily lives. I would also like to thank the public for their support and patience during very dficult circumstances.:Cllr Casey added: ldquoWith our household recycling centres now closed to free up resources needed to maintain domestic refuse collection services and help ensure compliance with social distancing guidance, we are appealing to people not to fly-tip and to do their bit to keep the district clean and safe..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre to be community hub
story: DOWN Leisure Centre has been transformed into a new community co-ordination hub to ensure that vulnerable residents across the district receive essential supplies.Set up by Newry, Mourne and Down Council, the Downpatrick hub is one of three that have been established across the local authority areas.Others have opened in Kilkeel and Newry but the distribution centres are not open to members of the public or community groups.Local council officials have been working in partnership with their colleagues across local government, health trusts and the Department for Communities to set up the hub which is to play a key role in delivering the service on the ground.Down Leisure Centre mdash which has been closed to the public for the past month as a result of global pandemic mdash has been transformed into a processing centre to organise deliveries, with other sites currently being identied should they be required.When fully operational, over  leisure centre staff will be redeployed to work across all sites and work alongside others from across the organisation to help operate a lsquovirtualrsquo hub to coordinate the response.Staff training is currently underway for those who will be working in split shts at the centres while observing social distancing and other safety protocols.The service was formally launched on Monday across the councilrsquos seven even district electoral areas, with deliveries expected to centre on food supplies.In addition, a COVID- community helpline is already operational, with those in vulnerable groups seeking support can make contact between am and pm, seven days a week.The Freephone number is   , while the email is covid@adviceni.net. Contact can also be made by texting ACTION to .The helpline is being managed by Advice NI who are processing calls from across Northern Ireland.All calls that are relevant to the councilrsquos community co-ordination hub will be passed on to the local authority for action, including referrals from the South Eastern and Souther health trusts.In addition, the County Down Rural Community Network in Downpatrick, the Confederation of Community Groups in Newry and Community Advice Newry Mourne and Down will also be acting as lead organisations for the community groups involved in this response. Any volunteers required are being recruited via Volunteer Now.Council chairman Charlie Casey is encouraging those in vulnerable groups needing help to contact the freephone helpline.ldquoFrom the outset of our coronavirus response, we wanted to make sure we could reach those in the district who might need our help the most, he said.ldquoThis is a very dficult time for all of us and we want to make sure that our most vulnerable residents have access to essential supplies. No one should feel they are on their own so please donrsquot hesitate to get in touch on   you need assistance.The council chairman thanked everyone involved in getting the new coordination hub up and running, explaining that he is aware of the hard work going on behind the scenes over the past week.He added: ldquoI commend those in the community and voluntary sector who have been working with us and the other statutory bodies to put these plans into action.More information on the COVID- community helpline is available at the NI Direct website https:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles coronavirus-covid--advice-vulnerable-people..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 8%2C 1980
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash More than , Apprentice Boys invaded sun-drenched Ballynahinch on Easter Monday for a big rally in the town.Apprentice Boys from  clubs in Down, Antrim and Belfast, accompanied by  bands, took part in the parade to mark the th anniversary of the formation of the Ballynahinch branch.Thousands lined the route from the assembly point on the Old Belfast Road to a field at Millbridge on the Downpatrick Road.The speaker at the field was the Rev William Beattie, DUP deputy leader, and he told the audience that Loyalists would never yield to the SDLP proposal for power-sharing in government between Unionists and Republicans.Mr Beattie said power-sharing was not only a dead duck since  mdash it had now been cremated. He said that when Secretary of State Humphrey Atkins meets Eire Foreign Affairs spokesman Brian Lenihan in Dublin later this month, he should remember his Governmentrsquos pledge that the future of Northern Ireland was a matter for the people of Northern Ireland, her Majestyrsquos Government and the Parliament of the United Kingdom.Mr Beattie said Mr Lenihan should be warned that Loyalists would not tolerate interference by Eire in the internal affairs of Ulster in order to prop up the SDLP or in any SDLP proposals for power-sharing or a Council of Ireland.ldquoMr Atkins should take note we will never surrender to any pressure from Dublin or London that would hasten the arrival of a united Ireland. We would rather die than submit to Republicans, he declared.DOWNPATRICK mdash Down Cathedral has been desecrated by vandals. The cathedral was entered on three occasions mdash on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.Two collection boxes were forced open and the contents stolen. More than pound was taken and police also found that the front door, which had been forced open, was badly damaged.They also said excrement was littered around the balcony and that someone had urinated in the building.STRANGFORD mdash The Strangford car ferry service experienced its busiest ever Easter period in its -year history. There was a marginal increase of  on last yearrsquos record total of , cars carried across, although the number of passengers using both ferries ped from , last year to ,.Inevitable delays developed in both Strangford and Portaferry as the two ferries tried to cope with the rush of motorists to the Ards Peninsula and Lecale coast.Easter Sunday was a particularly busy day for the ferry crew with , cars and , passengers being carried across mdash a considerable increase on last yearrsquos figures. Monday was again the busiest day of the year with a staggering , cars using the crossing and , passengers.The ferry superintendent, Mr Louis Fitzsimons, paid tribute to the work of police in Strangford in keeping traffic moving. The new one-way system in the village also seemed to work well with little congestion or snarl-ups.NEWCASTLE mdash Thieves made off with jewellery valued at more than pound, when a jewellerrsquos shop in Newcastle was broken into on Tuesday morning. The target was a shop belonging to Mr H F Law and the thieves shattered the main window, collecting what they could before making off.Detectives have released details of the jewellery stolen and warn that the thieves may try to pass these off at markets across the province. They appeal for anyone who is offered any of these items to contact them immediately.The haul included a heavy gold identity bracelet worth pound,, three ladiesrsquo gate bracelets valued at between pound and pound, a gold chain worth pound, a gold necklet with diamond earrings to match worth pound and two silver necklets valued at more than pound.KILLYLEAGH mdash A bumper week-long festival is on the cards for Killyleagh this year. Instead of the usual one-day event, six days of fun are planned, from Monday, June , to the following Saturday.The organisers, the local Town Committee, have only tentatively discussed the festival idea, but in the next two months they will be anxiously working behind the scenes to map out a sparkling package of entertainment.They intend concentrating on getting clubs in the town to run events such as discos and dances, and they aim to tie all these into an enlarged festival programme.It is unlikely any blueprint will be drawn up before the end of the month, but it is believed the usual finale of a late night open-air dance has been ruled out. Instead, more emphasis will be placed on childrenrsquos activities and other novel events, such as a car slalom.KILLOUGH mdash Down District Development Committee are to seek a meeting with the management of the firm which owns the closed Killough brickworks. The committee are anxious to meet the firm, Tyrone Brick, and to find outthere is a market for the Poroton brick made at the brickworks.CASTLEWELLAN mdash Complaints have been received by police in Castlewellan about the frequency of cattle wandering on the roads in the Leitrim, Ballyward and Ballylough areas.Farmers and persons who have lands taken in these districts are requested to check their fences and gates as uncontrolled animals on the roads are liable to cause accidents, police say.KILKEEL mdash Mr Mervyn McErlane, a Kilkeel schoolteacher who ed into a lake to rescue a man in dficulties, has been awarded the Royal Humane Societyrsquos Testimonial on Vellum.The citation says that two workmen launched a home-made rafter on Dromantine Lake, Jerretspass, Newry, but less than  yards from shore the raft broke up and one of the men got into trouble. Mr McErlane, who was on sick leave after a heart attack, swam out and towed the man back to safety.COMBER mdash Thieves broke into st Comber Presbyterian Church on Saturday and stole pound from a cupboard. The next day the Gillespie Arms in The Square, Comber, was entered and pound stolen from the till.Also over the weekend, there was a break-in at the Commercial Vehicles premises in Killinchy Street and a caravan used as an office was damaged. Comber police are investigating the incidents and would welcome any information.CRICKET mdash Downpatrick Cricket Clubrsquos bid to win the Northern Cricket Union title this year has received a tremendous boost by the signing-up of an Australian professional this week.Rex Bennett, a  year-old opening bowler and middle order batsman, is due to arrive in the county town with a fortnight, in time for the opening game of the new season.The clubrsquos decision to sign a professional was taken several months ago and it was through the negotiations of chairman Bob Law that the deal was clinched.Bennett will become the first Aussie professional in Northern Ireland. A right arm fast medium bowler, he will add some impetus to the Downpatrick attack and his middle order batting should steady the locals in a position which has given them trouble over the past two seasons.RALLYING mdash Two of the five local drivers competed the gruelling Circuit of Ireland Rally on Tuesday morning, the other three dropping out over the exhausting five-day event.Ernest Kenmore, from Killinchy, and Comberrsquos Craig Canmore were the two who proudly drove through their cars through the finish line at Belfast City Hall, although the main honours went to Scotsman Jimmy McRae, who was the overall winner.Other local drivers taking part were Warren Craig, from Downpatrick, Brian Dickson, from Seaforde, and Stanley Orr, from Killinchy..prettyPhoto

title: Gridlock
story: THEof motorsport action to Bishopscourt racing circuit has been ruled out until August the earliest owing to the coronavirus pandemic.Circuit officials have been forced to a cancel a number of meetings, which would normally provide a major boost to the local economy.The first casualty is this Saturdayrsquos Enkalon Trophy meetingmdash one of the biggest of the year and which includes round of the Ulster Superbike Championship.Also cancelled is a touring car meeting scheduled for May -, a karting event on June  and a big charity meeting in aid of Air Ambulance Northern Ireland the following day.The Donny Robinson Memorial meeting in July, which includes another round of the Ulster Superbike Championship, has also been called off.A meeting for classic motorbikes, due to take place in August, is still on, but whether it actually goes ahead is doubtful.The Easter weekend usually brings out motorbike fans in their thousands. Another victim of the pandemic is Easter Mondayrsquos Ulster Superbike Championship meeting at Kirkistown.Bishopscourt circuit manager Roy Biggerstaff said: ldquoIt terribly disappointing. Wersquove already had to cancel the Temple  meeting, which was due to take place on March , and included the first round of the Ulster Superbike Championship.ldquoThe only motorsport we have had here this year is a rally stages event on March . Since then we have been completely shut down.ldquoCoronavirus is having a big impact on motorsport here at Bishopscourt and on the local economy. Motorsport brings major economic benefits, particularly for bars, restaurants, bed and breakfast accommodation providers and shops.ldquoThe Enkalon Trophy is usually one of best supported meetings of the year and the charity meeting for the Air Ambulance was going to be massive.ldquoI have been involved in motorsport for a long time and this is as bad as I can remember. My phone hasnrsquot stopped with people calling and wanting to know what is going on.However, Mr Biggerstaff said sport was much less important than the need to safeguard public health and save lives.ldquoThe health and welfare of the public is the major concern right now. Our hands are tied until the coronavirus pandemic dies down and then we will take our guidance from the Motorcycle Union of Ireland Ulster Centre, which is our governing body.He added: ldquoI hope motorsport fans and the public in general understand the situation and that everyone is trying to their best. When this pandemic ends we will come back bigger and stronger..prettyPhoto

title: Holy Week message to give people hope
story: WE see the strange sight of clergy preaching to deliberately empty churches. It is certainly a strange experience for me.I was ordained in  in Downpatrick. New technologies and new means of communication came after that, and Irsquove struggled ever since. So the recent experience of having to install web-cams at short notice into the three churches in my two parishes of Portaferry and Ballygalget, has been somewhat traumatic.This week is the holiest of weeks for Christians. The passion and death of Jesus is commemorated, in preparation for the resurrection on Easter Sunday. We celebrate this in ious ways. We might well ask ourselves what happened to Lent and how on earth do we celebrate what will seem like a lsquovirtualrsquo Easter Coronavirus suddenly intruded into our Lent, at close quarters, and changed everything.My mother still remembers the glow in the sky over Belfast, when from her home in Ballykinlar, she heard the planes over South Down on their way to blitz Belfast. No doubt her grandmother would have told stories of the terrible pandemic of Spanish Influenza just over a century ago.But my generation and that of my nieces and nephews have known little of such things and we experience this pandemic a grave threat.At the moment of writing, the streets of Portaferry and Downpatrick are entirely empty, as are the great cities of Rome, London and New York.The unexpected severity of lockdown leaves us feeling bewildered, disorientated, shell-shocked. We are acutely aware of the suffering around us mdash illness, hospitalisation, loneliness in sudden isolation. As schools close we are anxious about increased tension in family le. The loss of our work and leisure patterns, financial and employment worries.In the Old Testament Jobloses so much of what he had mdash health, family, possessions and friends mdash yet he refuses to rebel against God in his suffering. This is incredibly dficult for most of us. His attitude of acceptance of his suffering can be of help to us. He says: ldquoShall we receive the good at the hand of God, and not take the bad Jobrsquos story can be useful to us at present. If you can get a chance, read it.Lent mdash an old English word for spring mdash is more challenging this year than we ever expected. As we celebrate Holy Week here are two words that figure in the writings of Henri Nouwen, a Dutch spiritual writer, that I find useful.The first word is security. Where do we look in our lives for security. A basic human need  In success, popularity, money, friends, family, insurance and so on  We mightnrsquot think we do. We will always be influenced by them, but deep down they will never provide us with security.Many of those things are good in themselves, but spiritually, the only true security will be found in the everlasting love of the One who loved us first and who wishes to love us into and for all eternity. Job understood that mdash security.The second word is patience. Patience means a kind of ldquosuffering through the present. Itrsquos from the Latin, patior, which means to suffer. But being patient does not mean sitting back and doing nothing. It is not being passive. Having patience is not easy for us. How do we wait patiently for God this Holy Week, Easter and beyond during this world pandemic Being patient is an active waiting mdash it means a certain experience of suffering through the present moment. To let the seeds of our suffering be sown in the ground so as to grow later into healthy, strong plants.It means avoiding the dead-end of what could have been for the ability to pay attention to what is happening before our very eyes, paying attention to the people and world around us. By that patience, we can begin to catch a glimpse of the first rays of Godrsquos glorious coming.Last week, I personally saw those first rays when I witnessed the staff in a residential nursing home in Portaferry decide to live-in with the residents for as long as this emergency would last.This week I witnessed those first rays when a cousin, a retired doctor, rang me to tell me he was volunteering toto work to bolster the Health Service.In one way or another have we not all been privileged to witness the generosity of spirit, despite danger, of those carers, nurses, doctors, medics, ancillary staff and many others Might this not be for us another glimpse that helps us experience in our present circumstances that Christ is indeed risen and lives now among us  It certainly is a glimpse for me.The Old Testament reading for many of us on Sunday last was from Ezekiel. ldquoThe Lord says this: I am going to open your graves. I mean to raise you from your graves and lead you back to the soil of Israel. I shall put my spirit in you, and you will live, and will know that I, the Lord, have said and done this it is the Lord who speaks.The people of Ezekielrsquos time knew their frailty and experienced uncertainty as we do today. Their faith in God had been severely shaken. Could they start again Security, patience, maybe these two words might stay with us over the next while as the reason for the hope that we have I leave you with the words of a psalm, which St Patrick himself echoed in his own writings, his lsquoConfessionrsquo.The words encourage us to place our hope in the Son of God who will sustain and strengthen us in our days, the Son of God, Jesus, who knew what it was like to stumble and fall beneath the weight of the Cross. With these words I ask God to bless us and keep us safe:ldquoI waited, I waited for the Lord and He stooped down to me, He heard my cry. He drew me from the deadly pit, from the miry clay. He set my foot upon a rock, and made my footsteps firm.With security and patience we can put our trust in the fallen saviour..prettyPhoto

title: Huge boost for foodbanks
story: THE districtrsquos foodbanks have been provided with a pound, boost by Newry, Mourne and Down Council to help them respond to increasing need during the coronavirus pandemic.The funding has been provided via the local authorityrsquos community network and is one of a series of initiatives the local authority is spearheading to continue providing a range of frontline services and responding to the needs of the vulnerable and elderly in particular.This week, residents across the district have been thanked for adhering to advice to help stop the spread of coronavirus by staying indoors and keeping safe.And, as the Easter weekend approaches, council chief executive Marie Ward has appealed to people to continue to listen to the advice to stay at home and save lives. She said everyone has a duty to stay well and help prevent the spread of this virus to reduce the pressures on health staff.Mrs Ward said the local authority appreciates the efforts people are making at this challenging time, while the districtrsquos first citizen, Charlie Casey, said ldquowe are in this together and reinforced the stay at home message.The chief executive said council staff have put in place measures across the district to ensure that the organisation can continue to deliver services to the public, confirming that a number of new services have also been created to support communities through COVID-.She said that bin collection services continue without interruption, with other staff being trained for redeployment to frontline services.Mrs Ward explained that since mid-March the council has put social distancing measures in place for staff in bin lorry cabs and fitted special screens, explaining that given the size of the refuse collection service, in the current crisis it is subject to daily changes.She continued: ldquoWe recently announced the development of a community coordination hub to ensure vulnerable residents receive essential supplies and it is now in operation.ldquoWe have been working in partnership with colleagues across local government, health trusts and the Department for Communities to set up the hub, ready to play its part in delivering the service on the ground. We expect deliveries to start going out to vulnerable groups this week.The council chief executive said leisure centres have been repurposed as processing centres to organise deliveries across the council area, with sites currently being identied should they be required.ldquoWhen fully operational, over  leisure centre staff will be redeployed to work across all sites, with other staff from across the council helping operate a lsquovirtualrsquo hub to coordinate the response. Staff across the organisation are also working in ious ways either through remote working or redeployment to other key services, continued Mrs Ward.The council chief said the organisationrsquos regeneration and business development team has been working with the business community to respond to the challenges they are experiencing due to COVID-.The council chairman said he recognised that as Easter approaches, it will be a dficult time for many as they spend it apart from families and friends.He continued: ldquoI appreciate the efforts made by residents to stay at home and exercise social distancing and understand how dficult this will become as time goes on. Please know that we are all in this together.ldquoWe need to continue to get the lsquostay at homersquo message out, listen to our health experts and trust that collectively we can all help to reduce the spread of coronavirus. Please do not be tempted to travel to visit family and friends over the Easter period.The chairman thanked council staff for all their work, in particular binmen whose efforts have been praised on social media.He added: ldquoIt is reassuring to know that our community hub is now in place to deliver essential supplies to the most vulnerable residents. If you have been in touch with the Freephone helpline for support, items will be delivered to you.ldquoAs we work through this ever-changing situation it is important to remember that we will come out the other side. This will pass and the council will have a major role to play in the recovery phase. It is now more important than ever that we keep looking to the future..prettyPhoto

title: Locked
story: KILCOO will have to wait until May at the very least before they can start their defence of the Down league title.The defending league champions and All-Ireland club finalists were due to open the season with a testing encounter at Mayobridge on Friday evening.Divisions  and  of the Down All County Football League were to begin this weekend mdash with Divisions  and  were scheduled to start last weekend.Any thoughts of ato action have been put on the back burner with last weekrsquos announcement that the GAA shutdown has been extended until April .However, it has been revealed that there will be no competitive GAA action in Down in April mdash eventhe lockdown ends on April .Down GAA secretary Sean Og McAteer said last night: ldquoWe are staying in line with the GAA directive at national level, but there will be no games for adult or junior teams in Down in April.Mr McAteer said the decision was being taken for practical reasons. ldquoEvenwe were to come back on April , the clubs would need at least a couple of weeks to prepare. It would be very dficult for them to play in April.Mr McAteer said the battle against coronavirus had to take precedence over sport.ldquoThese are terribly dficult times and the most important thing at the moment is to keep people safe, he remarked. ldquoThere will be a time in the future for Gaelic games.Meanwhile, the gates of GAA facilities throughout the county remain padlocked.In their joint statement last week GAA director general Tom Ryan and president John Horan ordered clubs to close their facilities completely.ldquoThis is to include the use of all pitches and property for recreational purposes, including walking, casual games or gatherings, their statement said.ldquoWhere it is not possible to restrict access please erect signage to the effect that all GAA facilities are closed and all activity suspended.Clubs have also been advised that they can continue with membership registration while being ldquomindful of the possible changed financial circumstances of members, while club lottos may proceedthey are run on an online basis ldquoand do not involve wholesale engagement with the public.The statement added: ldquoClubs are also advised to refrain from undertaking new capital projects while support funding for this type of work is suspended..prettyPhoto

title: Mentoring service for businesses
story: TWO local councils have come together to offer small business a virtual one-to-one mentoring service.Newry, Mourne and Down Council and Ards and North Down Borough Council have announced signicant changes to their new Digital Growth Programme, which is a free online service and includes four digital webinars.To ensure there is no delay in the provision of the project during the social distancing guidelines due to coronavirus, the programme is now being delivered lsquovirtuallyrsquo.The programme, which helps new businesses learn new skills and develop confidence in using digital s and technologies, will now be delivered online from this week.The project is part funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development will be now be delivered remotely and online with each business receiving one to one tailored mentoring sessions from a digital expert.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Charlie Casey said: ldquoIt is a challenging time for businesses and we have worked with the programme delivery team to make important changes to how the Digital Growth Programme will be delivered to ensure we can act now and guide people through this uncertain time.ldquoWe will work with the businesses that have successfully been awarded a place on the programme on a one-to-one basis to help put plans in place now to ensure they have the tools and know-how to act during and after this uncertain time.Cllr Casey said there was also the potential of helping hundreds of other local businesses through the introduction of four lsquoGo To Webinarsrsquo which will take placed on Tuesday, April , Tuesday May , Wednesday August , and Thursday, September .To be eligible to take part in the Digital Growth Programme lsquoGo To Webinarsrsquo, your business must be located in either council area.To apply for one-to-one mentoring support, or to register for one of the four Webinars, go to www.thedigitalgrowthprogramme..prettyPhoto

title: Plans to upgrade Ardglass harbour could cost £45m
story: AMBITIOUS plans to redevelop Ardglass harbour could cost in the region of poundm, a new report has revealed.The figure is contained in a detailed consultants report commissioned to undertake an in-depth feasibility study to look at potential developments for the harbour which is home to Northern Irelandrsquos third largest fishing fleet.The key issue the consultants focused on was deepening the harbour to facilitate larger vessels, with work also undertaken to look at improving harbour conditions, berthing pontoons for smaller vessels and increased berthing facilities.In addition, the study included a comprehensive review of possible harbour layouts, historic document research, topographic and bathymetric harbour surveys, quay wall inspection above and below the waterline and computermodelling.The consultants also liaised with the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswhich has been given a copy of the consultants report ahead of further discussions with its officials on the way forward.Ardglass has the only all-weather harbour between Howth and Bangor and has three primary areas including the so-called fish dock within the south pier.There is also the Phennick Cove marina located behind a breakwater mdash which could be extended mdash to the west of the main harbour which can accommodate up to  leisure craft and the inner harbour which dries out at low tide.The consultants say that the inner harbour is particularly useful for vessel maintenance but not utilised as extensively as the outer harbour due to limited water depth.Last August, ious concept layouts produced by consultants were reviewed by members of the Ardglass Harbour Developments group which has been set up to oversee the regeneration of the port. The concepts were subsequently amended in November.The prime focus is on deepening the harbour and moving forward, a cost effective approach may be to zone dredge levels in particular areas.The report suggests deepening the outer harbour by nine metres and the area adjacent to Cochranersquos building at the inner harbour by two metres to facilitate crab vessels.In addition, consideration is being given to creating a pontoon with so-called finger berths adjacent to the quay wall in front of Cochranersquos with gangway access for crab vessels. No leisure craft would be permitted at this part of the harbour.Removal of the existing slipway at the southern end of the harbour adjacent to the beach is suggested as it is not generally used and considered too deep for access, with potential issues in relation to the removal of an area know as Church Rock to be investigated.Quay reclamation work is suggested between the north west corner of the existing finger pier at the ice plant and north western tip of the fish market quay.This would feature a new piled quay, backfilled and surfaced with a heavy duty concrete. Extending theof the quay wall by  metres is also suggested.The estimated cost of the harbour dredging is in the region of pound, with piling work and the new quay line and reclamation work estimated at poundm and poundm respectively.The breakwater extension is estimated at pound.m with the new pontoon facility estimated at pound,.The consultantsrsquo report makes it clear that the costings include primary construction elements but does not include licensing fees, site investigation, engineering design and tendering costs.Before anything happens, a marine licence is required for specic site investigation work, rock quality design and testing, sediment sampling of overburden, contamination testing and an environmental impact assessment.The regeneration jigsaw also requires detailed design work and planning approval ahead of tendering and construction.An economic appraisal may also be required.News of the proposed investment at Ardglass harbour comes after the portrsquos importance to the Ardglass fishing industry to the district and wider South Down economy was highlighted during a recent meeting with Stormont fisheries minister Edwin Poots.He met with South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran to discuss planned improvement work at the harbour, with the politicians also highlighting the need for additional investment in the harbour and its infrastructure.They described Ardglass harbour as ldquostrategically important for the Co Down fishing fleet, highlighting its crucial role in driving the South Down economy and its location as a central hub for processing fish landed at the port.Mr McGrath and Cllr Curran say further investment is ldquocritical to allow Ardglass harbour to expand to provide an economic boost, not only for the village but the wider area, and create new jobs..prettyPhoto

title: Please stay in
story: ldquoHE was my superman ndash the moving words from Loughinisland woman Maria Farrell whose father sadly lost his battle with COVID-.As her sister also lies in hospital fighting the virus, the mother-of-two has bravely spoken out to warn others not to be complacent about the deadly disease.Maria, who buried her father on Sunday, warned: ldquoIf you think you are exempt from this or you are immune to COVID-, you are barking up the wrong tree.ldquoMy dad went really quickly, hersquos tackled prostate cancer, heart attacks, falls, you name ithellip and hersquos bounced back. But this took him. I was so proud to call him my daddy, he was my Superman.ldquoI just want you all to know that this is real, so look after yourselves, look after one another and together we will fight it.ldquoHonour those around you, keep your distance, wash your hands, and remember you are not stuck at home, you are safe at home.Her father,  year-old retired bus driver Jackie Farrell, died at Altnagelvin Hospital, Londonderry, last Thursday ndash just a day after he was admitted.He had been cared for at home by Mariarsquos family with the help of two social care assistants.The youngest of seven brothers and sisters, Maria is originally from Strabane, but has been living locally with her partner, Jim, and their two daughters - Beth , who attends St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, and  year-old Taylor, who is currently a student at Manchester University ndash for nearly  years.Maria, whose mother Mary died some years ago, said her family did everything in their power to ensure that Mr Farrell, who had  grandchildren and  great-grandchildren, was kept as safe as possible in the previous weeks.ldquoWe had to all come together to do this and hence social distancing was impossible for some of us as two people were sometimes needed for care, explained Maria.ldquoWe did take precautions with gloves, sterilising as much as we could, washing our hands constantly, plus sanitising door handles and gates, etc.She said it was a ldquonightmare when her family discovered her father was sick at the same time as her sister, Ursula.ldquoThe very day our daddy was brought into hospital, Ursula was also taken in with suspected COVID- which has now been confirmed. She continues to battle in Altnagelvin Hospital, said Maria.ldquoItrsquos like a nightmare. As daddy passed over, our sister lay in another ward in the same hospital fighting for her le. Although when daddy did go, he must have used some of his magic as our sister started showing small signs of recovering which is slowly continuing, thank God.Maria said that her family wanted to keep him at home for as long as possible, knowing that when he was admitted to hospital with suspected COVID-, they would not be able to visit him.ldquoWe had to let him go and were heartbroken. But we were reassured by the amazing nurses at Altnagelvin providing regular updates and reading out our text messages for him to hear, said Maria.ldquoHe went downhill very quickly, but remained alert enough to know his time was up and made a remark when looking at a photo of himself and mummy saying that lsquoIt wouldnrsquot be long now Maryrsquo.Mariarsquos family do not know how their father contracted the virus and he only showed slight symptoms of the virus at the end of his le.She thanked people from her home town for showing their respects ndash as best they could ndash as his funeral cortege passed by on Sunday.Maria sadly added: ldquoJackie Farrell was a very special man. He was one quite like no other. I and the rest of my family spent our lives adoring, admiring and idolising him.ldquoHe was our hero. He had ears that truly listened, arms that always held, love that was never ending and a heart that was made of solid gold.ldquoWe always had great fun and good humour togetherhellipthat COVID- canrsquot take..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians urge start date for Ballynahinch bypass
story: STORMONT roads minister Nichola Mallon has been urged to meet with local politicians to discuss a start date for the multi-million pound Ballynahinch bypass.The appeal has been issued by Rowallane councillor Billy Walker, who said while the minister has ldquosignicant other priorities to deal with in relation to the coronavirus, she hopes that when the pandemic ends, she will agree to meet with Newry, Mourne and Down councillors.The local authority is seeking a meeting with Ms Mallon to discuss the need for work to start on the near two-mile bypass linking the townrsquos Belfast and Newcastle roads.However, Ms Mallon said that while she recognises many in the local community support the provision of a bypass, she has inherited a ldquosevere and challenging budget constraints.In a letter to the local authority, the roads minister confirmed her support to find solutions that deliver better for communities and improve lives across Northern Ireland.Ms Mallon said she will be assessing the pressures across her department, reflecting on her priorities and the commitments in the lsquoNew Decade New Approachrsquo document on the budget made available to her.The minister said it may be more useful to arrange a meeting with local councillors ldquowhen there is much greater clarity on these matters.Cllr Walker says he fully understands that Ms Mallon has a lot on her plate and hopes a meeting with her will take place once the coronavirus pandemic ends.He said while disappointed a meeting is unlikely to take place for the foreseeable future, he hopes that the minister will find time in her diary when thingsto normal, whenever that may be.ldquoThe Ballynahinch bypass has the potential to unleash a major economic boost for Ballynahinch and the wider South Down economy, he continued.ldquoThe bypass was first mooted four decades ago and is now at the shovel ready stage.ldquoWhen Northern Ireland gets back on its feet it will be important to invest in the local roads infrastructure which has missed out on major funding for far too long.ldquoA look at major road schemes in other council areas proves that when it comes to roads investment, Down District is very much the poor relation.Cllr Walker said that in addition to the Ballynahinch bypass, there was need for investment to complete the final upgrade of the A outside Saintfield between Doranrsquos Rock and the entrance to Rowallane Garden. He also highlighted the need for financial support for the southern relief road scheme in Newry.ldquoI fully understand that the roads minister has a lot on her plate and recognise that she is not responsible for the failure of her department to invest in any major road scheme in the local area over the past number of decades, he continued. ldquoThe bypass should be in place by now. Itrsquos potential for Ballynahinch and the wider South Down economy is immense.ldquoThe multi-million pound road scheme can rid Ballynahinch of its traffic nightmare, help rejuvenate the town and encourage more visitors into the district and wider Mournes area.South Down MP Chris Hazzard signed off the eagerly-awaited bypass in December  when hewas roads minister in a previous Executive.The by-pass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district, is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with roads officials insisting that it will greatly benefit both strategic and local road users by reducing journey times and improving road safety.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.It is also proposed that a section of the by-pass will pass under part of the Crossgar Road with a  metre long bridge constructed to take traffic over Ballynahinch River.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the by-pass where major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane..prettyPhoto

title: Recognition for poet Stephen
story: A BALLYGOWAN poet is celebrating after his debut anthology was recognised by two major awarding bodies.Stephen Sextonrsquos If All the World and Love Were Young was awarded the highly acclaimed American E M Forester Award which was previously won by Seamus Heaney in .His anthology, published by Penguin Books, was also shortlisted for this yearrsquos Shine Strong Award ndash an award presented annually to the author of the best first collection of poems published by an Irish poet.Stephen says his work centres on coming to terms with the death of his mother, Elizabeth, who passed away in .He said: ldquoI started writing a book of poems that initially were meant to be frivolous and entertaining.ldquoHowever, as I began writing, the intense grief I was battling at the time came to the fore.Critics say what developed was a touching tribute to his mother which they described as a moving narrative exploring bereavement, family le, memories and loss.The judging  consisted of poets Colum McCann, Jhumpa Lahiri and Paul Muldoon.As part of his prize fund for winning the highly acclaimed award, Stephen received , to travel and stay in the United States.Downpatrick poet Damian Smyth, head of literature at the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, congratulated Stephen on his award.He said: ldquoThe sense is quickly growing on both sides of the Atlantic that Stephen Sexton is already one of those rare poets whose obvious and prodigious lyrical gts are matched both by accessibility and universality.He added: ldquoIt is poignant that the person for whom the whole book is an elegy ndash his late mother mdashnever lived to see the acclaim lavished on her son.ldquoHowever, there are few contemporary works which describe the human processes of grief, loss, hurt and how love survives and endures as memorably and as movingly as this one, with virtuoso technique and profound wisdom, which I have to say is already a classic. What an achievement that is and what a poet..prettyPhoto

title: Stay at home and help keep others safe%2C pleads mum
story: THEY tell you not to wrap your children in cotton wool but when you have a child with a le limiting condition it goes against every instinct not to do just that.With the arrival of COVID- I have been transported three years into the past to when my new-born baby, Lorcaacuten, was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis . I have been transported to a time that has changed my perception of le forever.People with CF have a faulty gene which means the mucus in their bodies is much thicker and stickier than in other people.They donrsquot catch viruses more easily than other people but when they do, it affects their lungs by causing inflammation and increasing the amount of the sticky mucus. This makes bacterial chest infections more likely, some of which are resistant to antibiotics, leading to a decline in lungwhich is the leading cause of death in people with CF.As parents, for the first sixth months of Lorcaacutenrsquos le we were consumed with the fear. We were advised not to visit baby groups, not to let people with colds into the house, not to take him to the supermarket on a weekend when it was busy, not to let him play in soil, wet sand, or day-old playdough as well as taking many, many more precautions to keep him safe.We also discovered that my mother-in-lawrsquos COPD and my fatherrsquos bronchiectasis meant that Lorcaacuten would always have to be careful around his beloved Nana and Grandad in case he caught an infection from them. For the same reason, he could never be within six feet of someone  with CF because of the risk of cross infection. My world would never mdash could never mdash be the same.We rarely left the house. I gave up my job in the RSPB and postponed my studies. Much of our time was taken up with the heavy burden of treatment for CF, including daily physiotherapy and antibiotics. I spent a lot of time campaigning for a cystic fibrosis drug, Orkambi, to be made available on the NHS.And I cried a lot.Over the last three years, le has become more lsquonormalrsquo but beneath the joy of every milestone has been the fear of taking risks that could shorten Lorcaacutenrsquos le at any time.During this time we have learnt that there are some risks you need to take in order to be happy. Lorcaacuten began pre-school as well as swimming, gymnastics, and football classes and I resumed my studies and began working a few hours a week.There has been a lot of stress and sleepless nights, a lot of handwashing, and a lot of happiness. With the support of the public we won the campaign for Orkambi, a drug which can slow the decline in lungby up to % and can be taken by around half of people with CF. Lorcaacuten started taking it at the end of last December mdash the champagne was popped and finally we thought we could start to relax a little.Sadly it wasnrsquot for long. During the wait for Orkambi, Lorcaacutenrsquos lungs had become damaged, after catching a couple of colds in March, he ended up in the wonderful Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children for  days of IV antibiotics to treat a long standing chest infection.During those  days I watched the horrying news that COVID- was spreading. I grew ever more disturbed at the lack of action by the UK Government. How could our amazing health service, stripped bare by  years of austerity and cuts, possibly hold up under the strain of COVID- Lorcaacuten was moved to a room further away from other patients, masks appeared and I watched the eyes of the incredible staff in the hospital become more and more tense.With nearly every death I read that the patient was either elderly or had an underlying health condition. But why did that make it OK: Surely that made it worse  The message seemed to be that lsquoonlyrsquo the vulnerable were at risk but other peoplersquos lsquoonlyrsquo is my everything.As the days in hospital passed, I learned that the lung conditions of my son, mother-in-law, and father put them among the , in NI on the extremely vulnerable list. They would need to lsquoshieldrsquo for the next  weeks. Shielding means not leaving the house at all and having to rely on the government and the goodness of others to deliver medication and food to your door.When Lorcaacuten was able to leave the hospital, we arrived home mdash with great relief mdash to a lockdown. Once again, with no job to go to and my studies on hold, I am transported to those months of isolation three years ago.This time, however, it is dferent, because this time I have hope. For us, this too shall pass. We willto the normality so hard won in our lives. We, unlike so many others who will lose their lives, will have this as a memory to pass on. I let so much of Lorcaacutenrsquos infancy be marred by fear that I just canrsquot let it happen now. Every day I am thankful for my good fortune in a desperately unfair world. I am thankful for all the frontline workers and volunteers, for the Executive finally working together for the common good to sustain us and to protect the most vulnerable in society, for the kindness of people delivering food and medication to those most at risk.I am grateful to the other souls sitting in their homes feeling helpless and feeling like le is passing them by. But by feeling helpless we are helping more people have a le toto after this all ends.It will end but the world will never mdash can never mdash be the same and none of us will look at it in the same way either.Maybe it will be a world in which those who need support will begin to get it, a world in which our NHS will finally be built up rather than worn down, a world we protect rather than profit from. As I watch Lorcaacuten run happily and healthily around our safe home with his little sister, Saorla, I donrsquot feel fear for him. I feel fear for those putting their lives at risk for all of us, for those who will lose their lives and loved ones, and for those who are sitting in their homes feeling afraid.I often think that doing nothing is the hardest thing to do, but for the moment doing otherwise is a risk too great to take, for us all. If you can, embrace the cotton wool,only for a while..prettyPhoto

title: Workload up for Good Morning Down staff
story: THE Good Morning Down charity which provides a telephone befriending service to elderly and vulnerable people across the district has increased the number of calls it makes as the coronavirus takes hold.Volunteers who work for highly acclaimed charity mdash now in its th year mdash have relocated from the organisationrsquos base at the Down Business Park in Downpatrick to their homes to ensure that the friendly voices people have come to rely on continue to be heard.Good Morning Down has also confirmed that in addition to increasing the number of calls that it makes, it has moved some people off the servicersquos waiting list in order that they can receive a call at this worrying time.Since it launch in , Good Morning Down has supported over  people with a wide range of disabilities and needs and the service it provides to people who live alone has never been more important.While there is concern among the senior citizens they contact and who have been advised to remain in doors for the foreseeable future, there is also great stoicism, with several able to recall hardships that they had to endure during World War Two.Staffed by  volunteers, the charity normally makes around  calls between Monday and Friday but the number has increased to help reassure elderly and vulnerable people that they are not alone.Relocating staff away from their main hub at Innovation House, the charity is unable to pick up any messages that may be left on the Good Morning Down answering machine. To help overcome this a new mobile telephone number is available mdash  .Good Morning Down was established to help reduce loneliness and isolation. Volunteers also signpost those who need further support to other agencies.Good Morningrsquos Down service has never been more important. One of the charityrsquos volunteers, Aidan Harris, says the current climate represents a challenge for everyone, particularly those who live alone.ldquoThe staff moved out of our base at the business park over two weeks ago, but we are providing the service from our own homes and what we are doing is very much appreciated by those we contact every week, he explained.ldquoWe certainly are living in unprecedented times none of us have ever experienced anything like this in our letimes and hopefully will never do again.Aidan explained that while a lot of information people need to hear is circulated via social media, many elderly people do not have access to it. In the main, he said they are relying on the television and radio.ldquoWe are letting them know what is happening and reinforcing the message to stay indoors and not let anyone into their home, even their own relatives. We are highlighting the importance of them doing all that they can not to catch the virus, the charity volunteer continued.ldquoPeople are very concerned at what is going on and many of those whom we contact used to get out to attend ious clubs but they have all closed due to the pandemic which means the elderly and vulnerable are spending even longer alone in their homes.Aidan also revealed that some who normally received only one call a week are now getting several more, with people brought off the waiting list so they can be contacted.He also revealed that the charity is also providing the people they contact with details about local shops which are providing a delivery service.ldquoWe are emphasising the hand hygiene message as much as we can and reminding people to stay indoors. We are also telling them to exercise social distancing and not let anyone into their homes, he said.ldquoWe are also telling those whom we contact not even to let one of their neighbours over the door as it is simply too risky. The people whom we contact are very concerned about what is going on but they are made of stern stuff.Aidan added: ldquoAll the volunteers are working hard to make sure we maintain contact with our clients, more regularly than in the past by increasing the number of calls we make to them.ldquoThe reward is how grateful they are for the service we provide and our main goal is do all we can to let them know that we are here for them and want them to keep safe..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week.
